150268968.review:
[h1]Despierta en un mundo de ensueño[/h1]

Primer juego desarrollado por Supergiant Games, con un equipo de apenas siete trabajadores, quienes afianzaron con este título estar en el punto de mira de público y crítica por igual. Controlamos a un personaje denominado simplemente como Kid (chaval) por un narrador que crea e hilvana la historia conforme la cuenta. Al principio simplemente nos levantamos de una cama con el objetivo de ir al Bastión que da nombre al título, donde los supervivientes de El Gran Desastre han acordado reunirse al primer indicio de problemas. Mediante algunos diálogos, textos y sueños se verá que hay mucho más, sobre el protagonista, el mundo que nos rodea y el pasado que lo dejó todo sumido en el desconsuelo. Es un planteamiento original y muy interesante.

El título es un juego de rol de acción con acceso a varias armas (cuerpo a cuerpo y a distancia) que podremos mejorar, habilidades activas y licores que actúan como habilidades pasivas; todo visto desde una cámara con perspectiva isométrica sobre la que no tendremos control. El combate es simple debido a la limitada forma de atacar pero cada arma consigue transmitir una sensación tan distinta que, una vez encontrada la combinación que nos resulte más cómoda para cada situación (podremos usar dos armas a la vez) se siente especialmente bien y en ningún momento se nos hará pesado. El desarrollo está basado en niveles (historia y desafíos de armas) de simple diseño pero muy detallados que los hace sentir plenamente diferenciados. El Bastión actúa como base central a la que volveremos al terminar cada nivel y que podremos expandir (con un máximo de seis estructuras) para acomodar a los supervivientes que encontremos durante la aventura. Al avanzar también tendremos acceso a [i]Quién Sabe Dónde[/i], una serie de desafíos oníricos (podríamos llamar) basados en oleadas de enemigos donde se expande la historia de los personajes. El juego tiene soporte para mando que, debido a la vista isométrica, resulta mucho más cómodo de controlar.

Con unos gráficos a base de hermosos dibujos hechos a mano en alta resolución, el juego se asegura que, sin importar el tiempo que pase, siempre se verá bien. Básicamente hay una única voz (en inglés) en el juego, la del narrador, excelentemente puesta por Logan Cunningham y con textos en castellano. La banda sonora tiene muchos toques del viejo oeste americano, donde los instrumentos de cuerda toman el principal interés y junto con otros ritmos más fuertes ocasionales le dan una identidad propia; sonoramente está a un gran nivel.

El juego tiene una duración aproximada de 6-8 horas para la trama principal, si decidimos completar los desafíos de armas, los sueños de Quién Sabe Dónde y mejorar todo al máximo, podríamos sumar otras 5 o 6 más. Una vez terminado tendremos acceso a una [i]nueva partida +[/i], un nuevo desafío llamado [i]El Sueño del Extranjero[/i] bastante más complicado que cualquier cosa que el juego te haya impuesto antes y poder comenzar una nueva partida en dos modos distintos: ataque con puntos y sin sufrimiento; el primero te puntúa por eficacia y el segundo es el modo fácil del juego.

Con una forma muy particular de contar una historia, un gran apartado artístico y sonoro y un combate simple pero satisfactorio debido a las distintas combinaciones de armas, [b]Bastion[/b] es un título muy recomendado para cualquiera.

150101188.review:
I'll always appreciate Bastion for putting Supergiant on the map. Of course, it's still a wonderful, mournful work of art. And it's still fun if you're not looking for something to sink your teeth into. But after Hades, if you were thinking of coming back for the score attack, it's really rough...

Basically everything in this game points to playing keepaway, kiting enemies, hiding behind cover. Enemies boil down to ones that chase you vs ones that snipe you, with only superficial differences. This means similar things apply to the weapons, which feel like you're simply choosing between different control schemes for skirmishing and sniping, rather than an actually different playstyle. Plus the autoaim behaves in frustrating ways, especially if you're trying to block/parry.

And activating any idols only exacerbates it all, and really cuts down on the viable weapons. You have to take the highest power single-hits you can find, and some melee weapons leave you too vulnerable (largely because they have unusably small hitboxes). Finally, most Skills i tried are just too low impact or leave you too vulnerable to matter, and without a training dummy it's not worth the tedium of sitting through loading screens to test the myriad of them out.

It all rounds out to pretty samey gameplay that, even though I got all the achievements without too much trouble, and I miss some of the weapons, I don't personally like enough to try harder to improve at in score attack. You really get to appreciate why Hades has back-attacks, a dash instead of a block, the bloodstone system for ranged attacks, a revised difficulty system, more complex enemies, and so on.

149839159.review:
[code]The game that started the success story of Supergiant Games remains a pleasure to play even more than a decade after its initial release, even with a few (technical) flaws present[/code]

It’s not often you see a game studio constantly delivering games that receive a MetaCritic score of 80 or higher – but developer Supergiant Games is one of the few that achieves this rare feat. All of the games the independent developer released over time have been hits with critics and players alike: [i]Bastion[/i] (2011, [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/bastion/]MC: 86[/url]), [i]Transistor[/i] (2014, [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/transistor/]MC: 83[/url]), [i]Pyre[/i] (2017, [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/pyre/]MC: 85[/url]) and finally [i]Hades[/i] (2020, [url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/hades/]MC: 93[/url]), their most recent game and the first one to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1145350/Hades_II/]receive a sequel[/url].

Based on this alone, it should come at no surprise that even their first game, [i]Bastion[/i], is definitely worth its money – mostly thanks to its excellent presentation. It features music by the fantastic Darren Korb, offers a superb dynamic narration by the Logan Cunningham and looks great thanks to an excellent art-style and -direction. Even those who might end up not buying/playing the game, should consider giving “Zia’s Theme (Build That Wall)” [url=https://open.spotify.com/intl-de/track/5DutiJxznQmcV5a5a1zfRW?si=6b41b2d6353345b8]a listen[/url] at least – it’s worth it.

The gameplay of [i]Bastion[/i] on the other hand consists of basic action role-playing combat. Protagonist “The Kid” can carry two different (melee & ranged) weapons and use one special attack to get rid of various enemies, more weapons and “secret skills” to equip unlock over the course of the story. Weapons can be upgraded once the required materials are obtained, although you’ll have to choose between two different options per upgrade stage (non-permanently, as choices can be changed later). If you want to delve deeper into the gameplay, there’s not only a score attack mode but also New Game+, various challenges and a totem system, the latter of which allows you to raise the difficulty of the game through various options in exchange for higher rewards. For all you achievement hunters out there: Yes, completing certain challenges while having a certain amount of totems active is required for various achievements. Thankfully, as you can individually choose to (de)activate totems, you can set the difficulty of the game just as you want it, from casual to hardcore.

The weapons play quite differently, so there’s a good chance you’ll find one you like – or one you hate. Unfortunately [i]Bastion[/i] forces you to use certain weapons during some parts of the game and while they can be switched out later on, I would’ve preferred choosing between keeping my old weapon equipped and trying out the new ones. Another small problem concerns ranged weapons: Thanks to the isometric perspective of the game combined with height differences of the maps, you might sometimes find out that your shots won’t hit their intended target but are instead blocked off by the environment.

As an action role-playing game, [i]Bastion[/i] is mostly about a constant flow of enemies you’re getting rid off while traveling to various levels chosen from a map. Some of the levels are about progressing the story while others are “weapon challenges”, which require you to fulfill certain tasks with a specific weapon (e.g. hitting targets with your bow, the less arrows you need the better the reward) but they can easily be ignored if you’re just going for a story playthrough. The combat itself is just what you expect: There are sixteen different enemy types to fight over the course of the game, using the genre-typical mix of attacks, ultimate attacks (called “secret skills” here), blocking and evading. It took me some time to adjust to the blocking and evading in [i]Bastion[/i] but it’s not a particularly hard game (unless you want it to be).

The combat works fine, mostly thanks to the different weapon/secret skill combinations you can choose from, even if enemy sometimes get stuck on the environment. It’s not groundbreaking but it’s a well-refined offering of what’s expected from the genre. I do wish that the story levels of [i]Bastion[/i] offered a little more than just constant enemy slaying, however. A little puzzle solving, or small platforming challenge (not just in the last level) would’ve gone a long way to mix things up, even if the game definitely isn’t outstaying it’s welcome if you’re just going for a story playthrough (which can admittedly be done in just about 4-5h). Even exploration is very limited thanks to the linear levels and mostly just a few dead ends that contain either upgrade materials – or just another health potion.

All of your actions in the game are accompanied by the previously mentioned dynamic narration by Logan Cunningham. It’s very immersive to hear the narrator react to your actions (e.g. your equipment or which path you’re taking first), although the mostly linear story levels make sure that the narration isn’t too dynamic after all. Speaking of tory: The vast majority of [i]Bastion[/i]’s plot is conveyed through this narration, which might not appeal to everyone. It also isn’t the most exciting or memorable tale, thanks to underdeveloped characters and a plot that’s mostly just there to tell you where to head next. It does offer enough unique worldbuilding and twists to not leave a negative impression however, it’s just not interesting enough to warrant a playthrough on its own if it wasn’t elevated by the excellent presentation.

If you just want to play through [i]Bastion[/i] once for the story, you’re looking at one afternoon as it should take about 4-5h of playtime to do so. Thanks to the aforementioned various optional content, ranging from weapon challenges to the score attack mode, you can spend a lot more time with the game, however. Additionally, if you play through the story once you’re only able to see one of the [spoiler]two possible[/spoiler] endings, so a New Game+ playthrough might be in order if you want to see it all. 

Lastly, I’ll need to talk about the technical state of [i]Bastion[/i]. While resolutions of up to 4K are supported, the in-game settings only allow you to choose a 1080p resolution at max. See the [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Bastion#Video]PcGamingWiki[/url] for a workaround. Additionally, the V-Sync option in the game still lead to screen tearing on my end for some reason, which is why I chose to disable it and enable V-Sync through Nvidia instead. I also have to mention that the German translation, while faithful to the English original, was not implemented well, as various loading screen tips were not fit properly and got cut off for example.

Still, even with a few flaws present, [i]Bastion[/i] is still a great game even a decade later. It’s no wonder it managed to start off the Supergiant Games success story and while it’s not my favorite of the bunch (that would be [i]Transistor[/i]), it already showed off just how good the independent studio is at creating games. Combine this with the low asking price and [i]Bastion[/i] is definitely worth a look for anyone searching for a well-executed indie action role-playing game with an excellent presentation.

149470990.review:
Bastion is one of the OG indie games, up there with Fez and The Binding of Isaac. The story is simple, the designs are pretty, and the gameplay is fun. When I finished the game, I said to myself, "Well, that was nice. I'm glad I played that." I've never played it since.

When I played through the game, I didn't experience any bugs, glitches, QoL issues; anything that would pull from the experience. There was easy parts, there were hard parts; I ignored some of the optional content, I beat some of the optional content. Bastion feels like the quintessential video game – the kind of thing you'd use as a retort to anti-gaming sentiment. You pick it up, you play it for a couple hours, then you go on with your life a little happier than before.

In a way, I think that makes Bastion the perfect game.

148249497.review:
I played about 80% of Bastion right after I bought it during a Steam sale. I was dedicating around 2 hours a day to it, but after 4-5 days, I found myself getting a bit bored and decided to take a break. Fast forward a few years now, and I noticed it was still installed on my computer. I made up my mind to finish the story, and that's exactly what I did tonight.

I was initially concerned about forgetting crucial details, but it all came rushing back to me about an hour into the game. Interestingly, towards the end, I unexpectedly found myself getting a bit teary-eyed. This came as a surprise, especially considering my (lack of) interest in the story due to the extended break in my playthrough. I guess it's a testament to the game's emotional impact.
The soundtracks are, as always, great, especially the ones where Ashley Barrett and Darren Korb sing.

One challenge I faced was trying to follow the story through the narrator's voice while combating enemies. I couldn't concentrate on what he was saying 'cause I lack multi-tasking, so I missed a lot of details. However, maybe now, on my new game plus playthrough where I can basically one-shot everyone, I'll be able to focus more on the narration.

[b] Update: Regarding the story(telling) my sentiment hasn't changed that much. It's mid at best :S [/b]

All in all, I'd say it's one of the games of all time.

[h2]In-depth[/h2] 
[h3] ⚔️ Gameplay & Exploration: [/h3]  
  
Bastion is a 2.5D top-down game that, at first glance, may appear to be a rogue-like, but that's not the case. It is the place where other games seem to have started and taken inspiration, and from which Hades, the developers behind Bastion, also drew inspiration.
It's a linear action game where you get to dodge, use a different variety of weapons, and obtain upgrades to overcome each challenge. Weapons are abundant and vastly different from one another, each with a large array of abilities.
Idols are also an addition to this game, offering you the ability to gather more spirits, which serve as your currency but also provide a great challenge in combat.
Additionally, you'll have challenges for each weapon you use to strengthen your skills and improve your reaction time in combat.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3047089592
 
[h3] 😄 Fun: [/h3]

It's a challenging game with peculiar platforming moments, yet it's not a bad one by any means. The story is captivating and interesting, keeping you intrigued for the most part. 
 
[h3] 🏞 Visuals & Presentation: [/h3]  
  
Personally, I found the art style to be somewhat harsh on the eyes. It's challenging to appreciate what's happening in the world, as everything seems rather randomly generated by these platforms and cubes. I didn't enjoy it much, and it was often quite difficult to see where you were stepping because of it. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3047956925
 
[h3] 🔊 Sound & Voice-Acting: [/h3]  
 
The quality of both the music and narration in this game is exceptional. I found great enjoyment in the storytelling as it was presented through the perspective of Rucks. 
  
[h3] 📖 Story & Writing: [/h3]  

In Bastion, the story revolves around the character known as the Kid, who finds himself in a world torn apart by a catastrophic event referred to as the Calamity. As the player progresses through the game, the Kid's primary objective is to collect special shards of rock scattered throughout the world.
These rock shards play a crucial role in powering the Bastion, a central structure within the game. The Bastion serves as a place of refuge and hope in the midst of the post-apocalyptic chaos. As the Kid gathers these shards, the Bastion gradually becomes more powerful and begins to rebuild the shattered world.
The narrative is rich and engaging, with the player unravelling the mysteries of the Calamity and the history of the world as they collect these crucial shards. The interplay between the Kid's journey and the gradual restoration of the Bastion creates a compelling storyline that keeps players invested in the game's world and characters. Bastion's narrative is an integral part of the gaming experience, immersing players in a unique and captivating post-apocalyptic setting.

147409027.review:
This is yet another game I bought many years ago, played for an hour, and then never touched it again. I'm glad I picked it up again on my Steam Deck though, as I really enjoyed playing through it this time around.

The story is probably my favourite part of this game. The narration is really neat, and the way it reacts to what you do is really cool as well. The game has a really unique premise as well, and the ending is phenomenal.

The gameplay is very fun as well. The movement and dodging feels smooth and there lots of different weapons and abilities to use and play with. It's not too challenging for the most part, although there's idols you can activate to give you much more of a challenge if you're the kind of person who likes that. The game auto targeting enemies can be a bit frustrating when a new enemy appears and the game switches targets unexpectedly, causing you to miss or get hit, although this does get a bit better once you get used to it. The vast number of different weapons in the game also meant that I sometimes felt like I didn't have much time to use one before another weapon was thrust into my hands. These are both minor gripes though, and I had a fun time with the game overall.

The game ran very smoothly and I didn't encounter any bugs or performance issues on the Steam Deck, and the game looks great. The music is also fantastic and made the story and the overall experience even better (the end credits song is beautiful).

[b]TL;DR[/b] This top-down action game has a very unique and interesting story with fantastic narration, great gameplay, good stability, outstanding visuals and music, and ran perfectly on the Steam Deck. I enjoyed it and would highly recommend it, especially if you're looking for a great story and soundtrack.

146880890.review:
Bastion is not just a video game; it's a work of art that showcases the potential of storytelling in the gaming medium. Developed by Supergiant Games and released in 2011, Bastion stands as a timeless example of how a small indie studio can create a truly remarkable gaming experience.

From the moment you start playing Bastion, you're immediately struck by its stunning visual design. The game's hand-painted, vibrant world is a marvel to behold, with each environment meticulously crafted to create a unique and captivating atmosphere. The world literally forms beneath your feet as you move, adding a dynamic element to the already beautiful landscapes.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Darren Korb, is a perfect accompaniment to the visuals. The music seamlessly blends with the on-screen action, setting the tone for each moment, whether it's a thrilling battle or a poignant story sequence. The narrator, voiced by Logan Cunningham, is a standout feature, providing dynamic commentary that responds to your actions, making the world feel more alive and immersive.

Bastion is an action role-playing game that excels in blending real-time combat with strategic depth. Players take control of "The Kid," the game's protagonist, as he navigates through the shattered remnants of a once-vibrant world. The combat system is responsive and offers a variety of weapons that cater to different playstyles. Experimenting with different loadouts and strategies is a rewarding experience.

The most innovative aspect of Bastion's gameplay is the dynamic level design. The world literally assembles itself as you explore it, creating a sense of wonder and unpredictability. This unique feature keeps you engaged and adds an element of strategy as you choose which paths to take.

However, the game's controls can feel a bit clunky at times, especially when using ranged weapons, and this may take some getting used to. Additionally, while the core gameplay is engaging, the overall challenge level is moderate, and some players may find it lacking in difficulty.

What truly sets Bastion apart is its exceptional storytelling. The game's narrative unfolds through a captivating and emotionally charged story, narrated by Logan Cunningham's gravelly voice. The world of Bastion is filled with intriguing characters, each with their own unique background and motivations.

As you progress, you uncover the history of the world and its people, and your choices impact the outcome of the story. This dynamic storytelling approach makes every playthrough a fresh and personal experience. The narrative is deeply touching, exploring themes of loss, redemption, and the consequences of one's actions.

Bastion offers a good amount of replayability, thanks to its New Game Plus mode, which allows you to carry over your weapons and experience into a new playthrough. This feature encourages players to try different strategies and story choices, providing a reason to revisit the game multiple times.

Bastion is a masterpiece that combines beautiful visuals, a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack, engaging gameplay, and a deep, emotionally resonant narrative. It's a game that transcends its medium, leaving a lasting impression on players. While it may not offer the most challenging gameplay, Bastion's storytelling prowess and artistic excellence make it a must-play for anyone who appreciates the art of video games.

145223106.review:
Finally catching up with a classic from Supergiant Games ! I was excited to play it.

First of all, I loved the narrator with his voice weaving through the story, intertwining with precise moments and actions, creating an immersive experience that gives life into the game's world. For a seemingly "simple" game, the depth of the lore attached to it was a pleasant surprise. The world felt alive and it kept me hooked. Very well complemented by the music, Darren Korb is back at it again with another banger score.

I also loved the idea of the land that rejuvenates itself as you tread through it. The gradual restoration is a nice touch, guiding you along a linear path. It's a smart move, preventing potential monotony that could arise from this kind of linearity. Also, I think it was well-integrated with the lore.

The mechanics are quite simple, perhaps a bit too simple. The diverse arsenal of weapons offers a nice range of playstyles, but let's be honest, I often found myself just pressing forward and mashing that attack button (in normal mode at least). The ranged weapons are overpowered and kiting back enemies was a breeze, sometimes too much so. Blocking is essential but it sometimes targets the wrong enemy. Moreover, the pace of the game is slow, I think swifter movement would have added more spark.

The pattern of the story is quite repetitive. Go get a this and that and come back. There are some mild changes but towards the game's end, it began to feel repetitive. The game can be done in around 6 hours or even shorter if you skip weapons challenges or the dreams (although the latter add lore). However, I thought it felt just about right. Longer would have been a stretch, but the game neatly balances its duration.

Overall Verdict: Bastion is indeed a great game. A cool concept, storytelling that hooks you, great music and gameplay that might lean towards simplicity but still manages to be enjoyable. It’s a classic and I’m glad I finally played it. I recommend it!

143240083.review:
I beat this one a few months ago as part of a Supergiant Games marathon. For a debut title, this is pretty damn good, but as you may expect it is not their best work.
The gameplay is the weakest aspect in my opinion. It's a fairly standard beat 'em up with some upgrades for you to peruse and some extra challenge awaiting dedicated in the form of New Game+. Not bad per se, but if you're only planning to do 1 playthrough like I did then it will get a bit bland without that extra challenge.
Despite my criticism of the gameplay, that is where my negatives end. The story is incredibly well told, and the narrator is such a good addition that I sometimes add a similar concept when drafting up some games with my friends. The plot is good on it's own though; I liked the fact that this world basically brought its own demise amidst all of the fighting, it's super compelling stuff
I will also commend the art and sound here. The environments are beautifully crafted, and each level has visual flair that feels one of a kind. The soundtrack adds to the desolate atmosphere a lot as well.
Bastion is a great game to kick off the Supergiant Library. It's an immersive and compelling game that never really bored me in the 6 and a half hours I played. If this looks like your type of game, or the narrator gimmick appeals to you, pick this one up. 8/10.

143193992.review:
Bastion is an imaginative and engaging action role-playing game, commended for its narration, music, art style, and story.

The silent protagonist, known as "the Kid", navigates a post-apocalyptic world destroyed by "the Calamity", while his actions are dynamically narrated. As the player progresses through the game, they discover more about this mysterious Calamity, its origins, and the effects it had on the world. The game's art style is colorful and captivating, the narration is superb, and the soundtrack is marvelous.

Overall, Bastion is an incredible experience. The gameplay is fun and challenging, and the visuals create a very surreal atmosphere. If you're looking for a charming and unique Action RPG, Bastion is definitely worth considering.

Existe una gran variedad de armas desbloqueables, las cuales se pueden cambiar y combinar como más se acomoden a las necesidades del jugador durante la progresión de la dificultad de esta entrega. Finalmente, en fases finales del juego, se nos plantean algunas tomas de decisiones interesantes para dar un excelente cierre a esta tremenda historia.

140610703.review:
After sitting on this game for around 10 years, I finally came back and beat it a few months ago in order to go through Supergiant's stacked portfolio. I imagine most people checking this game out in 2023 and beyond will have a similar reason for playing this. You either want to play all the games from this much praised studio, or checked it out after playing their more recent games.

Their current pedigree might set high expectations, but surprisingly enough, I think Bastion lives up to most of them. To start with the positives, everything that has to do with visuals, audio, and storytelling aged amazingly well. 

It's a very aesthetically pleasing game. None of the individual designs are quite as distinct or inspired as their future games, but it comes together so nicely, especially thanks to the game's gimmick of building the levels as you go through them. The cartoony aestehtic with exaggerated proportions and super-deformed characters also gave the titular Bastion quite a cozy feel once you build it up.

Music is by far the strongest point. There's a lot of it and it's consistently great. Chances are, you probably heard some of these tracks as background music for random game related videos, it's just so good that works really well both in the game and outside of it.

Lastly, the game has an extremely simple plot, but it works rather well by focusing on the characters and not overstaying its welcome, it grabs you more through emotion than any sort of complex storytelling or twists. Back around release it was often praised for the narrator, who didn't just sound good, but also reacted to player's actions in specific situations. I feel like the dynamic part of commentary is way limited and doesn't really amount to much, but it is kind of charming when it works.

Now the gameplay didn't age nearly as well as any of the other elements, and if anything, would probably just as bad when judging it on release.  Bastion is an extremely basic isometric action game. You carry two unique weapons (typically melee + ranged, but you can pick any combination you want), have a dash, and a shile that allows you to either block or parry. That's all there is to it. No fancy combos or complicated abilities. You can augment things, somewhat, by mixing and matching weapon upgrades, ultimate skills, and tonics that serve as perks with unique buffs and debuffs, but most of the combat remains very simple. 

The enemies are just as basic, they often have only one obvious and well telegraphed attack, and outside of minor variations, you fight them all in roughly the same way. The lack of enemies with unique attack patterns makes the combat extremely repetitive, which is only somewhat redeemed by the game showering you with new weapons to try, but despite decent variety, there's rarely a reason to switch things up, especially considering that upgrades make quite a big difference in damage towards the late game.

If you want more of a challenge, the game offers something similar to Skulls in Halo where you can toggle on unique modifiers that make combat more challenging, but most of it comes down to either frustrating RNG, or just outright buffing enemies in every way. True to most optional difficulties in games, it doesn't feel like it was designed around it, so it leads so some very uneven difficulty and levels of bull.

Probably most obnoxious part of combat for me was the fact that collisions often don't match the visuals, leading to many frustrating moments when your dodge just gets snagged on a rogue pixel, which is often enough to really mess you up if you got aforementioned skull turned on.

With that said, I strongly recommend playing this game on any of the default difficulty settings just to experience Bastion's unique setting, charming characters, and top notch soundtreck. It's a fairly cheap game, and you can easily go through the whole thing in one evening.

140522182.review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[b]The good:[/b][list]
[*]Beautiful world;
[*]Superb OSTs;
[*]Dynamic, engaging narrative;
[*]Simple yet fun combat;
[*]Great replay value.
[/list]
[b]The bad:[/b][list]
[*]Rare occasions of crashing;
[*]Quite short.
[/list]
[h1]FULL REVIEW[/h1]
[b]STORY[/b]:
The story is told through a narrator which is very easy to follow. I enjoyed the dynamic narrator's commentary on my choices and actions, which made me feel very immersed in both my character and the world. Couldn't expect anything less amazing from Supergiant Games.

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]:
Bastion isn't a difficult game nor is it a long one. The weapon options, upgrades, and combinations are very broad and interesting to use for specific or all levels. Different distillery options allow me to further customize my enhance, and the shrine allowed me to bump up the difficulty by a notch or two while rewarding me with increased rates of experience and currency drops.

Played the game with a controller as I found it a lot easier to control than kb&m. The interface isn't cramped with too much stuff, so navigation isn't difficult either. For one of the challenges I had to use my mouse, as I am awful at aiming with the controller lol

For those who experience crashing while trying to launch the game, I suggest downloading "XNA 4.0" from the official Microsoft website as this was the fix to my problem. The legacy solution exists for the game through Steam's settings, but it affects the visual look of the game.
 
[b]ACHIEVEMENTS[/b]:
Although the game doesn't have a lot of achievements, they will take a bit of time to acquire. A few are your typical story progression achievements, while the rest will require you to re-play the game 2 extra times (for NG+ & score attack mode) and complete four different dreams with all of the god idols.

[i]Achieved total completion and unlocked all achievements by June 22, 2023.[/i]

140062592.review:
After playing and absolutely loving Hades, I decided it was high time to check out Supergiant's other games, and decided to start with the original; Bastion!

At its core this game is very simple, but this simplicity is not necessarily a bad thing. You attack with two weapons that you can choose from a handful offered to you that you find over the course of the game and can use a dodge roll or a shield to defend against enemy attacks. The game keeps you on a pretty focused path, with minimal deviations for exploration, and those deviations that do exist tend to be small in size so you get right back to that focused path quickly. The game also has a few skill-based challenges for each individual weapon that have you trying to reach certain scores or times, and they're easily the most challenging thing the game offers. 

While you walk that path, you'll be accompanied by the charming voice of the narrator, who pretty much spells out the story and the events of the game as they happen. While in some cases a constant narrator could be a nuisance, in Bastion it actually works with a nice bit of sass and wit mixed in, plus the fact that the narrator is a character who is actually an unreliable narrator at times. The story is pretty self explanatory thanks to the narrator, but it isn't bad, and does give motivation to the characters in the world. 

The game isn't long, as I was able to beat it in about 5 hours. Despite being short, linear, and simple, this game has one thing that instantly and frequently endeared me to it; it had charm. The visuals were striking, the music was captivating, and the aforementioned Narrator kept my attention throughout the treks through its levels. The simplicity of the combat makes it very easy to pick up the game and get right into it, as there's very little learning curve. And the myriad of weapons gives a bit of replayability to the game, as you can mix things up by trying different weapon combinations for a different experience. 

If I had to find fault in anything in the game, the hitboxes are probably the biggest issue. They can be a little spotty at times, especially for melee, where sometimes the hitboxes don't match up with the animation. But this was more of a minor nuisance at times, rather than being a game-breaking issue. In addition, picking up a new weapon for the first time doesn't let you choose which weapon you replace, which can sometimes lead to sub-optimal setups, but this is only on your first time through a level, and several have armories to let you switch your weapon setups after getting a new weapon. And I cannot overstate how overpowered the shield is; the fact that it has almost no startup lag to bring it up means you can block any attack in the game as long as you're facing it. Sure, you can do last-minute shield blocks for added counter-damage, but even holding up the shield just to block can stun Melee enemies and give you an easy opportunity to retaliate. But none of these issues took away from the experience as a whole, and instead were just minor things I noticed while playing through the game. 

On a side note, it's absolutely fascinating to play this game after Hades, because you can very clearly see that a lot of the groundwork that Bastion laid gave rise to Hades. Several of the weapons in Bastion would later become more polished versions of the same thing in Hades, and it absolutely impresses me to know that Supergiant kept improving their work from their first game to their latest. 

Bastion may not be a groundbreaking game, but considering it's a 12 year old game and it was Supergiant's first game, it absolutely holds up. If you're looking for a short, charming adventure, Bastion is definitely it, and I highly recommend it.

[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Bastion"[/h1]

En 2011 apareció Supergiant Games y sorprendió con Bastion, propio de una época en que el sector Indie empezaba a ser valorado, y ya a más de diez años de su estreno es fascinante ver cuán lejos llegaron.

El narrador dinámico, la música y los escenarios hacen de ésta una experiencia brillante que se condice con su refinada jugabilidad, se hace evidente el cariño y trabajo detrás de este título.

Es una experiencia de acción breve pero intensa y calmada a partes iguales, algo muy complicado de conseguir.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Muy recomendable.

If steam had a middle thumb, I would give it that. Bastion does a lot of things right but fails on the most important part of a game. 
The art style, narration and sounds are all really nicely done. However, the actual gameplay is just boring and repetitive, and here's the problem with it. 
The combat actually has a decent amount of depth to be fun. There's a good amount of weapons, you can parry with a shield, you can dodge roll, you can hold down attack on certain weapons for a different move (usually range). However, the way the game presents itself makes it so that all these things are pointless and you're better off just running around as quick as possible spamming attack. 139034039.review:
Time for another blast from the past, this time Bastion from 2011.

I actually played through Bastion for the first time way back in 2012, when it took me about 12 hours to beat the game and do whatever side tasks I did back then. A decade older and wiser, I got through my first playthrough in under eight hours and mopped the rest of the achievements in another ten.

Turns out that Bastion is still a nice game.

You play as The Kid, a silent protagonist who has to smash and fight through a bunch of isometric stages that build around you as you move about the place. The core gameplay loop of Bastion revolves around combat, which is handled using melee and ranged attacks, a shield and special attacks. There is a handful of weapons to choose from, which unlock as you get through the story, and you get a choice of upgrades to further custoize your combat experience.

The combat itself is not particularly challenging, although you definitely can make things harder for yourself using the Idol system. About the Author, which requires you to defeat 30 waves of enemies in the Stranger's Dream while using all of the hardenings available, definitely gives you a run for your money. Even though I managed to beat it in two attempts, the first attempt failing at the last wave, it was not without its share of panic, screaming and aching arms. But if you don't reach for the Idols, combat's more on the relaxing side of the difficulty spectrum.

Oh, and if you decide to go for About the Author: Galleon Mortar and dodge roll, dodge roll, dodge roll.

There is a fairly short and basic story in the game, although it's not particularly gripping. Most of the interesting stuff in the Bastion universe happened before you even came along, and you're mostly told about it from the narrator. If you were hoping for a story-heavy game, you might be disappointed, but it's still a decent, somber narrative.

Bastion's art is highly stylized and gorgeous, although not perfect; due to the isometric perspective and the way the levels are designed, it's hard to tell which parts of the level you can actually access and which you can't. It's also not the easiest to avoid falling entirely off the level, which will snip some off your health bar as a punishment. Still, the overall quality of the art definitely offsets those minor annoyances.

The sound design in the game is absolutely top notch. I'd like to meet the person who doesn't enjoy Logan Cunningham's voice-over narration, which there is a lot. And Bastion's soundtrack ranks in some of the best video game soundtracks that I know of. It's the kind of stuff that you'll want to listen outside the game as well. I know I definitely have.

For my 2023 playthrough of Bastion, I did it entirely on my Steam Deck, as my gaming PC was actually out of commission for the entirety of it. And there is good news on that front: Bastion has a native Linux version and works absolutely flawlessly on SteamOS. Since this game is designed for a controller and is not graphically demanding, it makes for a perfect Steam Deck title.

Considering for how little money you can pick up Bastion these days, and the abundance of good things about it, avoiding it would be foolish if you feel like it would appeal to you in any way.

138940880.review:
Bastion was an ambitious game. You’d be hard-pressed to find such a magnificent debut from a new indie studio as this one. Bastion, the game of a young boy trying to repair his broken world, has a beautiful world, a beautiful narrative, and is told with the beautiful signature Supergiant style that they would come to be known for with games like Hades and Transistor. With all that said, I must admit Bastion is easily my least favorite of all the Supergiant games I’ve played. It’s understandable- this was their first game. This game is a huge accomplishment! But unlike their other titles, I have no urge to return to this game at some later date, and I think it’s mostly because I don’t jive very much with the gameplay.

Before we get to all that, though, let’s talk about the story and characters. Bastion introduces the magnificent story-telling prowess of Supergiant games with their narrator. Funnily enough, that’s probably why a lot of us had even heard about the game in the first place. I remember, long ago, my brother was excitedly telling me about this game where “they narrate EVERYTHING”. And I watched and listened to him play for a bit and, yeah, I was instantly intrigued. Despite very few characters and relatively few story beats, I was engrossed by the world, and I wanted to keep playing almost solely to hear what the narrator would have to say next. Otherwise, it’s a nice story with a meaningful choice at the end of the game.

But while the narrator was pushing me to uncover more of the story, the gameplay consistently held me back. And this might just be a “me” problem, and I might be alone here. Maybe it’s because I’m a relatively slow, methodical player, or maybe I just don’t like my games to be too fast? Or, more likely, maybe I just sucked at this game. It’s strange when I found the gameplay in other Supergiant games to be fairly compelling, but there was something off-putting about constantly falling through the floor when I’m trying to dodge attacks, constantly having to hit the heal button, getting spam-looped by heavy attacks that knocked me in the air, or taking constant damage from fifteen enemies on screen; the gameplay constantly had me feeling overwhelmed, and it just didn’t jive with me.

And it’s not necessarily the difficulty. I like hard games. Bloodborne is probably my favorite game of all time, and it still manages to kick my ass whenever I boot it back up. Sorry if you’re reading this and this is coming off as too vague, but I’m not sure how else to say it besides “I was feeling annoyed a lot”, and no number of new weapons or tonics ever made that feeling go away for me. What DID help some was doing the side quest to upgrade my weapons, but I had avoided them for most of the game because I was just trying to get it all over with.

Bastion has a lovely art style, but I did have one problem with the way they chose to portray the world: I only ever knew what something was supposed to be because of the narrator. The game would describe a section as “a market”, “a swamp”, or “a boat”, and I only ever knew I was looking at those things because the narrator said as much. So, I was never a huge fan of the environment or level design. I also always thought the kid’s character model looked a little wonky. One thing I was a huge fan of, however, was the music. Oh, man! The music boasts some of the wildest, funkiest tracks you’ll hear in an indie title, and it really did wonders to make this whole world feel weird and foreign.

This game is moderately repayable. It’s got all the usual replayability fixins like new game plus, lots of weapons to try out, and steam achievements. Not to mention the offerings to the gods you can give to increase the difficulty! But again, I had no urge to replay it, so your mileage may vary.

Bastion is a wonderful game, but it’s not really a game for me. I’d honestly rather watch someone else play it so I can listen to more of the awesome narrator. Despite my complaints here, I’m very glad I played through the game at least once. Maybe if you’re looking to see where Supergiant Games got their start, it’s worth checking it out.

138939985.review: Amazing game! The music and art style is absolutely phenomenal. The story is simple yet very emotional.

138935663.review:
Coming in at CDN$ 19.49, Bastion comes in at the perfect price for an indie game of it's size. Let's start with the obvious, Bastion looks quite stylish and beautiful, when the game never looses this beautiful art style throughout, remaining consistent no matter the location, effect or monster. Now for the meat of the game, the combat.

Bastion comes with a wide arsenal of unique and game changing weapons, you can equip 2 for every mission as a well as one skill. The weapons feel satisfying to use and master, the limit of 2 weapons allows the player to really way the pros and cons of the weapons they are carrying into the mission. With a simple but effective binary option weapon upgrade system, there are many possibilities for satisfying builds. One annoyance of this system is the game forcing the player to use a new weapon ounce it has been introduced, this can, temporary, ruin your build and make your life harder. Enemy attacks are well telegraphed and I never felt like the game cheated a death out of me, with one big exception, auto aim. When you block, a quite useful skill I might add, you are also pressing the button for the lock on, which snaps you to a nearby target, now this could be the completely wrong target and could lead to your death. If the problem is the lock on button, then why didn't I change it, well there are no options for changing the lock on button in the menu. If you're worried about difficulty, don't worry, Bastion comes with an idle system that allows you to change the difficulty by modifying the enemies stats for a reward, when you activate an idle, you get a boost in XP and shards (money).

In conclusion, if you like action games and have a spare 6 hours, I highly recommend Bastion.

138928904.review:
Ever since my days playing on the Sega Genesis, I have always enjoyed isometric games. In my opinion, this particular perspective and its top-down view work nicely by enabling fluid exploration, unobstructed controls and engaging combat. Some of the issues that plague third person titles, such as cumbersome cameras and movement, are not usually found in this subgenre, at least not in my experience. After many years of not paying attention, I finally took the time to try out Bastion. Intrigued by its screenshots and trailers, I thought this would be a pleasant ride. Unfortunately, although competently made, this game has a number of design decisions that made me disappointed, and therefore I cannot recommend it. Here's why.

Graphics-wise, Bastion is pleasing to the eyes, considering its launch date and overall direction. The artists did a nice job creating all these hand drawn objects, creatures and environments. I like seeing colors in games, and this one does not shy away from utilising them in a harmonious and effective manner. Animations are swift and simple, serving the game's cartoonish art-style quite well. Looking at this game's scenarios and effects, I couldn't help but remember my time with Little Big Adventure 1 and 2, which was an endearing feeling. My only gripe in this department is that, sometimes, large clutters of objects made grasping certain levels a bit difficult. Other than this point, there's nothing to complain about here.

Frankly, I don't have the technical credentials and knowledge to analyze in detail the sound effects of any game. I can say, though, that they are reasonably convincing in Bastion, if not a bit repetitive in the case of enemies. I haven't noticed any issues with chopped audio during my playthroughs, as everything works as intended. The only voice actor of the game, who voices the narrator, does a fine job in conveying his lines. Understanding them, however, is an issue depending on the amount of action currently on display. The soundtrack, despite its varied instruments for each level, didn't manage to entice me with any memorable tunes. Some songs became quite grating after a while, actually.

Bastion is an isometric action-adventure game with light RPG mechanics. Its gameplay revolves around traversing linear and unconnected levels, defeating multiple enemies in real time combat and collecting key itens used to restore a small village which serves as a hub. To dispatch foes, players have access to a selection of melee and ranged weapons, alongside a shield for blocking and parrying strikes and projectiles. Dodging is possible, but jumping is only allowed in a particular section at the end of the game, serving no higher purpose. To strengthen the protagonist, a number of beneficial traits and abilities can be purchased and allocated to perk slots. These slots are unlocked by leveling up, which is accomplished by killing hostiles. Money can be obtained from combat and the completion of minor side tasks and challenges.

Here's what bothered me. Beating levels in this game is a neverending trudge of walking on floating platforms. Everything is positioned either on small arenas or on connecting platforms that emerge as you approach their edges. Predicting the path ahead is bothersome because you aren't able to see it properly in many sections, despite the game's linear nature. I had this constant feeling of unease while moving since you're always at risk of falling down a precipice due to the narrowness of each floating path, which also made engaging foes a clumsy endeavor. Exploration is nonexistant, save for the occasional dead end with a collectible. Given that levels aren't logically connected between themselves, the world felt uninsteresting and irrational.

Combat is rather simplistic. This isn't necessarily a problem, but you're only allowed to carry two weapons at all times, and there isn't much to them. Players are restricted to performing regular swings or shots, as there is no elaborate combo system. The sole variation here is the possibility of using a single, mana dependent special ability, and most of these require specific weapons. Dodging is hardly useful as something more than a travelling technique -- your character moves around slowly and dodging constantly speeds you up a bit. The shield is effective against single targets, but proves itself unreliable in the presence of groups. Considering that walking space is constantly limited, facing these groups can be a problem, which brings us to the matter of difficulty.

The difficulty level in Bastion is entirely measured by the amount of shrine idols you apply to your playthrough. These idols can be unlocked as you progress into the main story and act as modifiers, increasing the challenge of combat in some way. Playing with no idols is a cakewalk, but when most or all of them are activated, enemies become gruesomely resistant and deadly, and not always in a reasonable way. Yes, you can upgrade your weapons at the blacksmith and change your loadout of perks, but I quickly found myself outgunned and cornered by these fully upgraded foes. It all feels artificial, as if the difficulty system was an afterthought. As a side note, I also think that the roster of enemies is a tad small. You end up fighting the same guys over and over again.

The story in this game is, well... I don't know, honestly. I could not follow nor understand it, and I suppose it is meant to be somewhat vague. Another gripe I have is that all actions and events are constantly explained and exposed by the narrator in his monologues. The problem is that most of his lines, as I implied before, are delivered during gameplay, often in combat situations. Perhaps I'm not a good listener, but I coudn't pay attention to them while battling hordes of enemies and trying to find my way around nonsensical floating levels. I just don't think that shoving tons of dialogues during action sequences contributes to an engrossing storytelling direction. The game presents these side characters that seem to be important, but their lack of expression and diminished presence made me indifferent to them.

So, yes, I don't think Bastion is an unmissable experience. You can tell the developers worked hard to make something worthwhile, and you can definitely indentify some shining aspects, which I respect. However, there are too many nagging flaws here for my personal taste. It might be worth a playthrough if you like isometric games, though. To end my review, I advise completionists to be cautious. Unlocking all achievements requires beating a bunch of special arenas with all idols activated. If you are unwilling to use cheese tactics found on Youtube guides, be prepared to suffer greatly.

138264262.review:
Bastion: A Captivating and Artistic Action-RPG Experience

Introduction:
Bastion, developed by Supergiant Games, is a masterful blend of stunning visuals, immersive storytelling, and dynamic gameplay. In this review, we delve into the post-apocalyptic world of Bastion and uncover the reasons why this action-RPG has garnered critical acclaim and a dedicated fanbase on Steam.

Visual and Audio Excellence (10/10):
Bastion's hand-painted art style is a visual feast for the eyes. The game's lush environments, vibrant colors, and detailed character designs create a mesmerizing world that feels alive and captivating. Coupled with a remarkable musical score, featuring a soulful narrator and an enchanting soundtrack, the audiovisual presentation of Bastion is a true work of art that enhances the overall experience.

Engaging Storytelling (9/10):
At the heart of Bastion lies a rich and thought-provoking narrative that unfolds through the eyes of "The Kid," the game's protagonist. As players navigate the shattered remnants of the world, they gradually uncover the secrets of the Calamity and the history of the Bastion. The captivating storytelling, coupled with the narrator's compelling voice acting, immerses players in a beautifully crafted tale that leaves a lasting impact.

Dynamic Combat and Customization (8/10):
Bastion offers a satisfying combat system that combines real-time action with strategic decision-making. Players have access to a wide array of weapons and skills, allowing for various playstyles and approaches to combat encounters. The ability to customize and upgrade weapons further adds depth to the gameplay, encouraging experimentation and personalization.

Unique Gameplay Mechanic - The Bastion (9/10):
The Bastion, a floating hub world, serves as the central gameplay mechanic in Bastion. As players progress, they can rebuild and customize the Bastion, unlocking new structures and upgrades that provide gameplay benefits. This mechanic adds a layer of progression and strategic decision-making, offering a sense of ownership and personalization within the game world.

Replayability and New Game Plus (8/10):
Bastion offers a New Game Plus mode, allowing players to carry over their progress and challenge themselves with increased difficulty. This feature, combined with optional challenges and secret areas to discover, enhances the game's replayability and provides additional value for players who wish to delve deeper into the world of Bastion.

Conclusion:
Bastion is an exceptional action-RPG that stands out for its striking visual design, immersive storytelling, and engaging gameplay mechanics. From the moment players step into the shattered world of the Calamity, they are treated to a visually stunning and narratively compelling experience. With its unique blend of real-time combat, customization options, and the intriguing Bastion mechanic, Bastion offers a captivating and unforgettable journey that will leave players enthralled from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of immersive narratives, mesmerizing art styles, or dynamic action-RPG gameplay, Bastion is a must-play title that showcases the talent and creativity of Supergiant Games.

137917275.review: I love this game to death, and no one I recommend it to seems to agree with me. I can certainly agree that some of the mechanics don't hold up to today's standards, and Super Giant's games have only gotten better with time, but this game still holds a special place in my art. The artwork, voice acting, variety of weapons (and therefore play styles) are incredibly well executed and should be experienced by as many people as possible. Not to mention the soundtrack. Truly, one of the only soundtracks that I actively listen to outside of the game, save maybe the Cuphead soundtrack. If you're a fan of Hades, or any of Super Giant's games, or even just want a quick little game to pickup, I highly recommend this. The game is frequently on sale for $2-3, so while I personally believe the game is worth full price, it's a great deal when on sale.

137812185.review: Cuando te gustan mucho los juegos de un estudio a veces vas hacia atrás a ver qué descubres y, aunque te puede gustar lo que encuentras, corres el riesgo de tropezar con las mecánicas de otra época o sus gráficos. Después de disfrutar con Transistor y Hades, he pasado por el Bastion y, aunque se siente un poco el origen de Hades, es muy gustoso. Un arcade con vista isométrica, visualmente cuidado y con un sistema de progresión de armas y habilidades cuyo único defecto lo encuentro en ofrecer demasiadas combinaciones. Además cuenta con un sonido/música espectaculares. Merece la pena dedicarle las siete u ocho horas que lleva completar su campaña y después meterse en las arenas a combatir un poco... o darle otra vuelta después de terminarlo.

137810244.review:
It's a small to medium length game but a great one. Everything about it is of great quality from the art direction to the gameplay, voice acting and music. It does not feel like the first game of a studio but like the work of veterans. The story is simple but flows well, the characters few but endearing.

The only flaws I can think of is that the perspective makes my character miss hits that should realistically hit and the visual cue for when a charged attack reach its peak is slightly too understated. Other than that, I have no complaints.

I think the game does a particularly good job at incentivising the use of all weapons through its reward system. I particularly like the challenge maps that teaches you how to use said weapons. Those maps are a bit of a challenge without being overly difficult, a balance I really appreaciated.

I enjoyed it enough that I will replay the  game in NG+ to finish levelling up and unlocking every upgrade/spirit because the experience itself beyond the story is entertaining enough that I don't want to end it just yet.

137527089.review:
I came to Supergiant’s games through [i]Hades[/i], and in some ways that worked against me in playing their very first game; I found [i]Bastion[/i]’s controls much simpler, and I was surprised at how much of a challenge I found it to adapt from [i]Hades[/i]’s controls. However, that challenge was not so insurmountable that I felt the need for No Sweat Mode (I appreciated its inclusion, even if I found – surprisingly, this is not my typical genre of video game – I didn’t need it).

[i]Bastion[/i]’s story is straightforward and linear. I wasn’t quite sure how seriously I was supposed to take the colonialist conflict between the Caelondians and the Ura; it sometimes felt like I needed to fill in some gaps in the game’s story. Nevertheless, I found the choice at the climax of the game poignant.

[i]Bastion[/i] has three outstanding strengths: 
1. its level design and its weapons. Every weapon in the game had a level for which it was best suited, so it didn’t feel like any of them were underdeveloped or neglected.
2. the art. Supergiant is known for its distinctive art style, and it’s a knockout here. It’s vibrant and colorful and doesn’t really look like a Western frontier and yet it evokes a frontier feel beautifully.
3. the music. Darren Korb has described it as “acoustic frontier trip-hop”, which is a vibe that never would’ve occurred to me, it’s pretty unique, but it [i]fits[/i]. I have never played a game for which its music fits so perfectly. It’s almost flawless.

137169261.review:
Bastion is the first game by Supergiant Games, perhaps now best known for Hades. I'm 12 years late to the party, but IMO Bastion still holds up to this day. It's got a distinct visual style, great soundtrack, simple controls and offers enough of a challenge for those seeking it. The narration by 'The Stranger' as you go through the levels offers a unique take on storytelling. I liked his style, but I can see how some would find it hit or miss.

I won't spoil anything, but the story of Bastion can be concluded in multiple ways. There's also a NG+ mode which retains your weapon upgrades, potions and character level. You can increase the difficulty by invoking up to 10 idols in the Shrine,  which in return also grants a passive bonus to EXP and loot. Some Steam Achievements are locked to NG+.

I played Bastion on the Steam Deck and encountered no usability issues.

137101151.review: Bastion is a novel take on storytelling in videogames. The game's narrator is a rather unique concept that enhances the gameplay in several ways. As you wander Bastion's excellent brush stroke visuals, The Narrator commentates over your actions as you progress through the story. The voice acting is, for the most part, fantastic, charming, and charismatic. Except for in a few optional challenges, the narration never gets in the way, and becomes an enticing part of both the gameplay and storytelling experience (I found myself poking NPCs and switching my loadout randomly just to hear more dialogue from The Narrator.) The gameplay itself is a lot of fun and has satisfying crit and block/counter mechanics. This game is a gem, with flaws so minor that they're not worth mentioning unless nitpicking. It's also very replayable!

Good 2d top down perspective game with an engaging story line and a killer soundtrack.
Your character has a variety of different weapons (melee and ranged) at his disposal, and can equip 2 at the same time. The weapons have a 3 level upgrade system which enhances some stats like damage, critical chance, spread, attack speed, status effects... You also have a perk system which unlocks as you level up, as well as a way to increase rewards and xp gain in exchange for a harder difficulty. This can be turned on or off with various degrees of reward/difficulty available.

The kid buys Bastion in 2021 for $3 on sale. Starts twice and quit, but always knew he'd come back. That's why they call it a backlog. The kid just needed to rage for a while.

I replayed the new game+ mode back-to-back, and it's more fun with all of the weapon combos, drink slots, difficulty modifier charms, and upgrades up front. The music and art style are top notch. The story is interesting about the horrors of war and other life concepts like moving on, and the combat feels fun. I usually played with 2-3 difficulty charms applied but you can play with up to 10, which would make the "no where" dreams as hard as anyone would want. I didn't want to ruin the fun by playing it that difficult but it's there for people who want it. It's about 7-8 hours long for the first play-through, and my second run was like 4 hours once I was more efficient and had all the items from the first run.

134873471.review: This game is amazing. The visuals are truly a painting, looking absolutely beauitful with interesting, variety, gorgeous drawn worlds and items. The narrarator did wonderful in telling the story and delivering his lines perfectly and the variety of builds, items, games, and replayability is insane. There is a reason that the game takes about six hours to complete, and thirty to a hundred percent. There is a wealth of content and the story is insanely good with a few choices that have you go through it again and again. The soundtrack doesn't have many songs, but all of them are fantastic and unique. The combat is really good, with every weapon feeling different with a different purpose to fulfill a niche and you can create some really fun combinations along with skills. I will say though, this game does have some jank. The proving grounds were okay, feeling a little dated as a mechanic and some were wildly easy, and the others were super super difficult. Also there was some stiffness with movement, and they hadn't nailed that perspective yet so sometimes it was hard to tell what you could or couldn't walk on, or certain hitboxes on your attacks as well as enemy's attacks. But overall this is a wonderful game, and the importance it has in being one of the first indie games to truly bring them to the mainstream is huge, and is the reason we've gotten so many wonderful indie games.

Here are several reasons to play Bastion:

The narrator's voice is smoother than a freshly buttered biscuit. Seriously, his voice could soothe a raging bull.

Who needs a therapist when you can smash everything in sight with a giant hammer? Bastion is the ultimate stress-reliever.

The world of Bastion is so beautifully hand-painted, you'll feel like you're playing in a living, breathing painting. You might even forget you're in your living room and not a museum.

The game's soundtrack is so good, it'll make your ears feel like they're on vacation. If you close your eyes, you can almost feel the sea breeze blowing through your hair.

If you ever wanted to be a superhero, but couldn't be bothered to work out, Bastion is the game for you. You'll be flipping, jumping, and smashing your way through enemies like a pro in no time.

Bastion's story is as deep as the ocean and as rich as a chocolate cake. You'll find yourself getting lost in the game's lore for hours.

Who needs friends when you have Bastion's weapons? From flamethrowers to rocket launchers, you'll have more than enough firepower to take on anything that comes your way.

You'll feel like a master strategist as you plan out your attack on enemy strongholds. It's like playing chess, but with more explosions.

The game's New Game+ mode will make you feel like a god among mortals. You'll be able to carry over all your upgrades and abilities from your previous playthrough, making you nearly unstoppable.

And finally, if you're looking for a game that's both challenging and rewarding, Bastion is the game for you. It'll push you to your limits, but the feeling of accomplishment you'll get after conquering each level is worth it.

131913261.review:
[i]Bastion[/i] is a very unique, fun and engaging title. Its art style, music, narration & narrative all intertwine, becoming a memorable experience worth having. Supergiant Games made something to remember with this one.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]

The gameplay has you, The Kid, waking up in an unusual place known only as “The Bastion.” It becomes your task to rebuild it and learn of the place’s history as you do. To accomplish this, you’ll set out on adventures to find and reclaim the components necessary to complete this task. You play from an isometric 3D perspective, hacking & slashing your way through wave of various enemies as the narrator talks of your feats and failures.

There is a simple upgrade system in place for each weapon in the game, as well as slight augments that can be paired with your weapons to further diversify your approach to each scenario you encounter. Enemies range from small creatures to large, daunting monsters, and every weapon will deal with them in their own unique ways, from being advantageous to outright incompatible.

The game never becomes particularly complex with its fights or puzzles, but accomplishes what it sets out to with flying colors.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]

Story-wise, [i]Bastion[/i] is a very different experience. Very little is explicitly told to you, and you must learn of the world through its few denizens and the companions you meet as you explore. It’s a basic-yet-touching story that’s worth experiencing. I will refrain from saying more, but just know that it’s satisfying, especially the ending.

[h1][b]Performance[/b][/h1]

Simply put, the game looks good and is easy to run. Because it’s rather dated at this point, most, if not all modern machines should have no issue running the title. The only major downside is the absence of any Borderless Fullscreen modes.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]

Bastion is a short & sweet experience with phenomenal music, narration, art direction and tight gameplay. It’s not too long, not too complex, but feels very rewarding to play.

130801370.review:
TLDR: Nice little gem, even though it's a little old. For how short it is, it's a good and well rounded game.

If you like dungeon crawler games that have a beginning and an end, this is a nice oldie. Nothing is random, though, so no loot drops and all that. 

Story; simple, nothing fancy here. Not impressive but certainly not garbage. The majority of it will be told by a narrator who will comment on some of your load outs, deaths and choices, which are a nice touch. I personally felt like the story was going to be bigger than it eventually was.

Graphics; it is a 2011 game, but the style has aged rather well. I liked seeing the world ''pop up'' as I walked forward, I thought it was a nice touch. The colours tend to be vibrant, which is nice change from the other bleak games I tend to play. 

Combat; for a decade+ game, it's held up surprisingly well... Maybe a couple of weapons feel off now, simply because they tend to be slightly clunkier than they would on a more recent game. 
You got your generic slower weapons with higher dmg, faster weapons with lower dmg, melee and range both. You can mix and match around a dozen weapons to whatever you think best fits your play style. There's also a leveling system, both for your weapons and your character. Everything is handled in a simple and smooth manner with just enough attention to details that you're bound to find a combo you'll fancy. There are also special attacks that will only work with specific weapons.

130662526.review:
'Bastion' is a short story, but also a really good story. As a game, it's not long. You can finish it in an afternoon if you're persistent. But in spite of the length of the main game, you'll find a deeply impactful narrative about the nature of power and what it means to wield it.

It's interesting for me coming to this after having played two of Supergiant Games' later works. I've gone through both 'Transistor' and 'Hades' and it's so easy to see the design progression that starts here. It's not as refined as either of those two later games, but the seeds are here and it's still really solid gameplay-wise despite it being the earliest attempt.

And how could I write a review of this without praising the music! Supergiant has an AMAZING track record of creating music that not just fits with the game, but also does its own share of heavy lifting in terms of world building. Listen to the lyrics of "Build that Wall" and consider who, in-universe, would have written that and what that person was trying to say. The story and world are so much richer just from this one song.

I don't have a lot to say about this one. Well... I do. I could spend hours breaking this game down and talking about the narrative importance of each of the characters and how they tie into the overall themes of the story. But those are all things that YOU need to go experience for yourself before we talk about it.

To conclude, I adore this game and wish I'd played it years ago. It's a hugely emotional experience and one that'll affect how I think about video game narratives for years to come. It'll probably be about that long before I can think of the ending without tearing up just a little bit too.

130124730.review:
🔵[b] Requires light tinkering [/b]

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable (Bastion.exe) on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

129687722.review:
Bastion was one of the first games I played through on Steam, way back in 2012. This review has been a long time coming.

Bastion is a game that I would still recommend to play in 2022 if you haven't yet. It's the breakout hit from Indie darling Supergiant Games and introduced us as to their signature style of storytelling and musical excellence.
It's short, my play time double most other people's due to me trying to get every secret, every challenge mission, and every achievement and I feel it's time well spent.

Bastion tells the story of a kid waking up to a broken world. Your actions are narrated as you go along and add to the ambience of the setting as you navigate broken sky ways and unlock the mystery of the titular Bastion.

The gameplay is isometric combat in levels, with a myriad of weapons to use. Several of which, in retrospect, found their way into recent smash hit, HADES. Which leads me to this...

If you're hoping for more HADES combat, it's not here.

This is Supergiant's first title and though still polished, it's not going to match up against HADES intensity or fluidity. The Kid does have the option to mix and match weapons to make a setup suited to your playstyle, and you'll find new weapons as you progress and it's always fun to try out a new one. The combat itself shows its age but, really, this game is about the storytelling more than combat.

Finally the music. To this day I have several Bastion tracks I regularly listen to and it's a disservice to yourself to miss out on them. The atmosphere of the game is incredible and only enhanced more by the music in tandem with Rucks' narration.

At the time of writing (during the Winter Sale) Bastion is $3. I bought it for the full price tag at the time I played and would still do so. For $3 though? If you're on the fence, take that leap. There is little reason to hold back from experiencing the game that started a fantastic string of titles from an equally great Dev.

129669996.review:
Running through and completing all of Supergiants other games before Hades 2 goes into early access. 

Bastion has been really fun so far even though its the oldest of the games. It has a lot of charm and soul in it and you can see all the things that it did that caused Supergiant as a studio to grow and evolve for Transistor, Pyre, and Hades. 

Even though I kinda knew a bit of the story before going into the game myself, the narrative still kept me really engaged in the game, and both the choices at the end were really hard ones. 

The gameplay is pretty basic but its pretty fun and theres a bit of skill to it with timing counter blocks with the shield and power shots with ranged weapons. You can also spice things up with the Idols that you get from the Shrine to make combat harder. 

The art and music are fucking amazing as always from Supergiant, its nice to see it was always that way even at their humble beginnings with Bastion. 

Overall I really loved this game even though I am extremely late to playing it, very cool and I'm really excited to see Hades 2 drop later this upcoming year. :D

129538096.review:
Hades is tied to my fifth favorite game ever. I was hyped for this. According to Steam, it took me 2.3 hours to finish the game, and it was an unenjoyable experience. Simply say, it's incompetent at anything that makes a 2d top down view combat game a good game: movement is bad, attacks don't feel good, ennemies are annoying and repetitve, aiming with the controller is straight up atrocious and it is overall so simple and non innovativce, I can't give any credit for creative mecanics. The game has very few mecanics, and fewer that are well done. The story is there, I guess, nothing creative I suppose, I genuienely didn't care, even tho I am usually a fan of story based game. Tho, I will say, there seems to be a lot of lore for the player to find. The visuals hindered the experience more than it helped Imo, ennemy were hard to see and could hide behind something that is visible from your character point of view, but not from the camera's point of view, meaning you'd get hit but wouldn't know from where. Also the whole gimmick of the ground forming in front of you is, again to me, interesting for about 5 seconds before it just become a way to slow the player down. This was a 1 hour and a half game extended by another hour by annoying mecanics, but it felt even longer by how slow everything is. 

Now, not all is bad, the soundtrack is good. 

This was only my opinion, I don't think the game is bad, I am just saying' I personnally didn't enjoy it, and wouldn't recommend it. If you liked it, great for you, I wanted to like it.
