128495791.review:
Primer juego de Supergiant Games, y les salió tremendo.

El hecho de que los dibujos sean a mano ya le pone muchísimo carisma al estilo artístico del juego. Y no se queda corto con el gameplay, ni con la BSO ni con la narrativa. Para ser un indie, es de los mejores.

Gran variedad de enemigos, de arsenal, de customizar a tu antojo cómo quieres jugar.
Una BSO chulísima.
Muy buen doblaje en inglés, especialmente la voz que pone Logan Cunningham a Rucks, ya que lo escucharemos todo el tiempo conforme avanzamos en la trama y en qué hacemos cuando estamos manejando al protagonista. Personalmente, junto con Doug Cockle (Geralt de Rivia), es de las mejores voces que he escuchado nunca.
Una narrativa interesante, que le da vida con cada detalle que vas encontrando en el juego. Además de alguna toma de decisiones.

Aunque hay algunos fallos de traducción, que aparece el texto en otro idioma. También peca de cometer los mismos errores de muchos juegos no doblados a nuestro idioma enfocados en la acción. Es decir, que a veces un personaje habla y necesitas en ese preciso momento estar concentrado en el gameplay, por lo que al final no puedes leer lo que ha dicho ya que no te dio tiempo o no pudiste mirar los subtítulos.

Así que sí, lo recomiendo. Muchos habréis empezado por Hades, pero merece la pena ponerse a jugar alguno de los anteriores. Siguen teniendo a día de hoy esa calidad de un estudio que le pone todo el cariño a sus videojuegos.

128322679.review:
So I started to write up a whole long thing comparing the indie film movement of the mid-late 80s and early-mid 2000s to the indie game design movement of the mid 2000s-early 2010s, reflecting on how in these types of "industrial" art forms there are these brief windows where the tools of production and distribution are sufficiently accessible but also the competition is relatively sparse and it becomes uniquely possible for nascent creators to make a mark for themselves with their scrappy, clumsy, deeply flawed but often innovative first projects, but then how within a few years those windows of opportunity always slam shut again as things get rapidly more competitive and the technology gets better and even the "independent" end of things becomes highly professionalized and the expectations of minimum technical competence quickly become inflated to such a degree that were those early pioneer works to be made just 5 or 10 years later they'd be considered amateurish or straight up [i]bad[/i] and go completely unnoticed... but then I got kind of lost in the weeds talking about Jim Jarmusch and Tom DiCillo and ended up deleting the whole thing.

ANYWAY, the point is that playing [i]Bastion[/i] today, the thing that stands out the most is just how clunky and stiff it is in just about every way—from the controls, to the animation, to the implementation of the mechanics themselves, to the way the climactic final level awkwardly forces you to both swap out a key movement mechanic with an entirely new one, and swap out both of your weapons [i]and[/i] your special attack with a cumbersome, kind of shitty new weapon that radically slows down the pace of the game and imposes a very specific play style. The thing that stands out the second most is how much this game serves as a trial run for a lot of the design innovations that would ultimately go into [i]Hades[/i].

I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone who's not a game historian.

128232077.review:
Pros: 
- Amazing soundtrack
- Great voice acting
- Beautiful art and level design
- Combat that is easy to start with and harder to master
- Ability to challenge yourself further by invoking Shrine Idols that raise the difficulty in specific ways (e.g. enemies deal more damage, enemies will randomly turn translucent, enemies never drop tonics and more)

128209706.review:
When the game came out it was a unique experience from an independent developer that nobody had really experienced before. Now that over a decade has passed, this game still has aspects that are unique but others that are not.

The narration, a selling point at the time, is definitely not as exciting now as it might have seemed when the game came out, but is still delivered in a way that is interesting, as the story unfolds at the same time the world literally unfolds underneath your feet.

Combat is not complicated, but aiming is a problem on a controller because some weapons require you to charge them up, which restricts access to the right analog stick, and auto aiming is not always reliable. I found the best combination of weapons was thus the shotgun and the pike, which trivialised basically every fight as soon as I got access to them.

I could have increased the difficulty of the game through using the shrines, but I'll be honest, there's so many games out nowadays that going for the highest score or most challenging gameplay on something that had the story as the selling point didn't really make much sense.

Speaking of the story, there are multiple twists and turns throughout, but I felt the impact of each story beat was muted by the Kid not reacting to it, as the majority of the story is narrated. The small amount of cutscenes made up of animated stills were more impactful, which is definitely helped by the beautiful soundtrack.

Overall, I do recommend this game if you wanted to know what an amazing indie game of 2011 looked like, or if you had some time to kill.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
+ Beautiful soundtrack
+ Visuals still hold up
+ The story and adventure unfolds in an interesting way

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
- Story didn't feel impactful except for the cutscenes
- Gameplay can be trivialised unless you decide to use shrine modifiers
- Leaderboards are ridiculous anyway so not much incentive to try and become the best

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Thank you, Bastion

It felt amazing when I first played it. 
Bastion was visually outstanding, not by stressing PC specs but because of it's unique style. 
When Narrator said his first words - he's voice mesmerized me, making me listen his every comment even in the heat of the battle.
Same did the soundtrack, taking it's well-deserved place in my MP3 player.
Difficulty was exemplary well-balanced: you can beat the game with some feasible effort and almost zero frustration -- or you can challenge yourself to get most out of it, and even more. 
Lore is another fascinating thing about this game: while never really destined to have sequel or another game set in this world, it's lore is still so well-made and rich that it almost hurts to leave it behind.  

This game was one of the most enjoyable things I ever played.

It still is.

127115119.review:
This game is one those strange games that you play because you've run out of AAA games to play or you just feel like a change from the epic open-world questing that is expected these days. 

It's the sort of game that you don't expect to play much and can easily forget. 

Except it's not. The continual narrative sucks you into the game and the lush, beautiful graphics keep you engaged while battling the various enemies that pop up along your journey. 

Did I mention that the soundtrack adds to this immersive joy, differing in so many ways from the generic meh that far more expensive games serve up with their products? No I didn't but it's so good it's worth listening to outside the game too.

If I had one HUGE complaint about this game, it would have to be that IT'S TOO DAMN SHORT.

The problem with getting sucked into a game as fun to play as this one becomes is that when it's suddenly over, you feel a little disappointed, even cheated that something that had captured your soul is suddenly spitting it out after a sub-10-hour journey. 

But what a great ride it was.

i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

bastion is an action rpg and is the first game ever developed by supergiant games. the game has levels that you move through, with the path forward forming as you approach it with a isometric camera view. there's enemies that you have to fight and there is also weapons you unlock as you progress through the game (you can wield any two at once). between levels you can use the game's form of currency to buy materials and upgrade your weapons in a hub world. this game is pretty universally liked and it's well deserved. the plot/story and gameplay are both very good and as a result the game overall is balanced as the plot/story doesn't become the only reason you're playing after a while but the gameplay isn't the only thing keeping you playing either. both are pretty good and mesh with each other perfectly. the narrator throughout the game is awesome and helps paint the picture of the world. the visuals are bright and energetic and the music is also a strength. overall, the game has very little in terms of weaknesses. the game isn't long at all (you can beat it under 10 hours for sure) but completionists like me will easily spend over 20 hours minimum to do everything in the game. this was supergiant's first game, but it was a great debut for them and i am very excited to play the rest of their games in the future.

124255414.review:
Bastion is a solid action RPG with some nice artwork, cool abilities and decent combat. However... I've played all four games made by Supergiant at this point (Bastion, Transistor, Pyre and Hades), and Bastion is my least favorite entry in the franchise.

Its combat is engaging, but slow and occasionally clunky. Its story is kind of interesting but not fleshed-out and refined enough (like Hades) or mysterious and bizarre enough (like Transistor) to be especially memorable. The visuals are nice, but not strikingly beautiful like Transistor or stunningly sharp like Pyre and Hades. It's obvious from a lot of mechanical and creative aspects of Bastion that Supergiant was still finding their footing with this game and hadn't fully hit upon the formula that makes their later games so amazing.

I still enjoyed Bastion, but it's hard for me to look at this game and not compare it to Supergiant's other titles when their other three games seem better than Bastion in pretty much every aspect. So... if this game caught your eye and you haven't played Supergiant's other games yet (especially Hades or Transistor), pick those up - they're more worth your time. If you've played those games and want some more, then try out Bastion. Just don't expect a masterpiece.

6/10

124177174.review:
I got this game out of curiosity because I heard it's short but sweet. I ended up spending 15 hours with it - I could end the review right here and that would probably be all you need to know. Go buy it and play it, Lunkhead.

If you're still reading, I can tell you that you're in for a beautiful, aesthetically pleasing artstyle, amazing, impactful sound design and heart-warming music. My only complaint in the presentation department is that there's no native support for resolutions beyond 1920x1080, so if you're on a 1440p or 4k monitor, it might look a tad blurry (but the game's artstyle makes it imperceptible, so it's not a huge deal). It's also locked at 60 FPS but since this isn't a game that needs hundreds of FPS, it was all fine and dandy.

This is basically a lite action RPG in isometric view, but the basic combat loop is super satisfying and deep without being obtuse or overly complex. You have a wide variety of weapons that you can upgrade and you can combine two at a time before heading on a mission, which accommodates a lot of different playstyles and I found myself changing weapons a lot because they were all fun to use and balanced out very well. You also have a "Distillery" which offers "Drinks" that give you passive buffs to customize your character further. The enemies are varied and creative as well. I'm being vague on purpose because I don't want to give too much away, I just really want to hammer home the point that the game is very well made and deserves top marks in the gameplay department.

It also has a very tight, short and heart-warming story of war, forgiveness and redemption. There's something wholesomely human about it, and I've never played a game back-to-back twice (NG+) just to see both endings (if you ask me, the [spoiler] Evacuation [/spoiler] ending is the better of the two).

I usually try and find at least something that could be improved in every review, but here, I'm left to nitpick and scratch my head. Apart from the minor technical stuff mentioned above, there's nothing really objectively wrong with the game. It's a bit short at its core (it can be finished in 4-5 hours if you rush through it), but it does have achievements, NG plus, an arena mode, upgrades to hunt down, trial maps for all the weapons, it's not like it's short on content, and it's all optional, which in today's day and age of stuffing big, open-world maps with tons of meaningless busywork, feels absolutely refreshing (even though this game is from 2011). If you don't like this type of artstyle, I guess you won't dig the game, but that's 100% subjective, so YMMV.

I'd say it's fairly priced at just under 13€ - you'll get your money's worth if you do the extra stuff; if you're only in it for the story, maybe wait for a sale. In short, Bastion is a superb game to spend a weekend with and it totally deserves your money and time. Great stuff all around!

123291334.review:
Bastion is one of the games that made me fall in love with indie gaming and now, a decade later, its still as fresh and good as it was when it came out.
Bastion is the debut game of Supergiant, probably the best devs around right now, and everything their later titles are famous for is true for Bastion as well; it looks beautiful, has a great storytelling, gameplay is simple but fun and engaging and soundtrack is god-tier.
It is a short game, however. You can finish the story in one afternoon. But, Bastion is a little game that packs a big punch; there are 2 endings, new game+, score attack mode and wave-survival challenges. Like Supergiant's last hit Hades, Bastion can be as easy or as hard as you want it to be. During the game you build a shrine which lets you evoke up to 10 gods, each one making game more challenging in a certain way. And if you like a challenge just invoke all 10 of them and watch as this fun and cool adventure turns into nail biting, reflex testing experience that would make From Software proud. There are also 10+ upgradable weapons, each requiring different gameplay approach, a bunch of different skills to use and various tonics that buff the player in some way. So, despite its lenght, there is plenty of replayability here.
Honestly, I can talk forever about how good Bastion is and I cant think of a single negative thing to say about it. Do yourself a favor and play it.
10/10

122283374.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1] 
[b]Bastion[/b] is an action-adventure set in a unique fantasy world. 

[h1]Pros & Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros:[/b]
+ Great soundtrack
+ Stunning visuals
+ Addictive action-packed gameplay
+ Interesting story with a very charismatic narrator

[b]Cons:[/b]
- New weapons break your preferred loadout
- Falling off the level while dodging is frustrating

[h1]Story[/h1] 
The game takes place in a unique fantasy world, that was shattered into pieces by something called the Calamity. You take control of a survivor dubbed the [b]Kid[/b]. As he makes his way towards the mysterious [b]Bastion[/b] he meets an old man named [b]Rucks[/b]. Together, they must gather a bunch of magical rocks to power up the [b]Bastion[/b] and restore the world to its natural order. Pretty standard setup for a videogame, yet the way this one delivers it is special. The entire story is narrated by [b]Rucks[/b] while you’re exploring the game’s world and fighting various enemies. Not only does the narrator give you lots of background information on things you see, but he will comment on the things you do. Which will instantly immerse you into this strange world. Furthermore, the narrator’s voice is so charismatic, that you’d want to keep playing just to hear more of him. There’re some plot twists that might feel predictable, yet they don’t feel like they were thrown in just for the sake of it. The ending of the game feels really cathartic and leaves you wanting more, just like any good story. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It’s kind of like hack and slash game. You can attack, dodge, guard with shield, use healing potions and perform special moves. The game offers a vast arsenal of weapons. You start off with a bow and a hammer and almost every level in the game introduces a new weapon to your arsenal. You can carry only two weapons at a time, but there’s no limit on which weapons you can select, e.g. you can take two ranged weapons or two melee ones if you’d want. Some weapons can be used in multiple capacities, like machete and spear, which can be thrown to eliminate enemies from a distance. There are lots of different enemy types, which can be more vulnerable to certain weapons, but the balancing is pretty good and there are no best weapons. So, you can select the ones that fit with your preferred playstyle. It also offers some difficulty customization. If you’re starting to feel like the game’s getting too easy, it allows you to activate modifiers that make enemies healthier, stronger and more fierce.  

Since the game’s world was broken to pieces, the levels look like floating islands. So more often than not, you will fall off into the abyss. Thankfully, it’s not instant death like in some games, it just takes away a small chunk of your HP. Although it becomes a bit frustrating at later levels, when the game throws everything at you. Lots of visual effects on the screen makes it very hard to see where you’re dodging. There are is also another rather frustrating moment. Almost every level introduces a new weapon and you can carry only two of them at the same time. So, each time you pick a new one, it will randomly replace one of your chosen weapons. This happens even in the new game plus, where you’ve already unlocked all the weapons. It breaks your loadout, leaving you with one weapon of your choice and a new one. So if your ranged weapon got replaced with a melee one, there are two ways to kill ranged enemies, one is to throw your machete/spear and the second one is counter-attack, and both take a lot of time especially if you use difficulty modifiers. 

[h1]Graphics & Audio[/h1]
The game really excels at this. Its visuals are just stunning. Every level is like a painting filled to the brim with details. There are multiple zones in the game, each with its own visual and music theme. Both audio and visuals work in tandem to create an engaging experience. The soundtrack has some memorable tracks that will stick in your head for hours. There’s only one voice actor, who you’ll be listening to for the entirety of the game, so getting wrong was not an option and they got it right. You won’t get tired of listening to the narrator because of his charming voice and a huge amount of charisma.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
Specs: AMD Ryzen 9 5900HX, NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3080 Laptop GPU 8GB, 32GB RAM.

On max settings, at 1080p resolution, the game runs at 60 FPS without any issues.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Bastion[/b] is an action-packed adventure with a charismatic narrator and a very satisfying gameplay. It hasn’t aged a day since its release in 2011. So, if you somehow missed it back then, I strongly urge you to play it now. This is an experience that will surely satisfy most gamers, from casual ones to the more hardcore ones.

122256546.review:
Having played Transistor before and seeing how much of a hit Hades is I wanted to see how Bastion was in terms of being their foundational title. And yes the isometric loadout focused action is certainly a trademark for Supergiant much like Ocarina of Time set the mold for the Zelda series initial foray into 3D: this is where the rest of them got their start and improved/varied upon it. But I think it highlights what Supergiant does best as theming. The attention paid to the artistic aspect of these games is fantastic. Bastion has delightfully styled visuals which are easy to understand, the music and narration is so very full of character, and with how tight the combat and core gameplay is it renders an entirely enjoyable and fun experience with actual replay value. Like its not that theres more stapled onto it at the end I genuinely want to keep playing to find everything and its visuals, music, and voluntary approach to difficulty makes that possible. 

TL;DR Fun combat, visuals and music is great. If you have Transistor or Hades then you will find familiar gameplay with another fully realized flavor of art.

Bastion was a rough game for me to get into and enjoy. Years back, I tried playing it through and just couldn't make it through. I did my best to play it while considering it's tenured release date, and really attempted to appreciate what this game brought to the table.

If you're wondering if this game is worth a purchase in 2022 and want to explore the hype of a modern 'classic', I just cannot recommend Bastion. It fails to keep things fresh. The 9 hours spent beating the story felt like 30, and I just couldn't wait to finish this title.

121900051.review:
Now, please remember that everything I'm gonna say about this game is while keeping in mind that it's over a decade old, so whatever you take away from my review, please remember that this game is 11 years old!

I bought this game because after hitting almost 100 hours in Hades I decided I wanted to play everything that Supergiant had to offer, and this is their oldest game available on Steam. And honestly? With 96 hours in Hades and remembering what games looked like over ten years ago, "Bastion" met just about all of my expectations. 

The art is just gorgeous in a very distinct early 2010s way, the music fits the atmosphere just nicely, there's a pretty good assortment of enemies for the length of the game and I was honestly delighted with the sheer number of weapons we have to choose from! The level of difficulty wasn't disappointing either, because in the first run there were moments when I genuinely struggeld to stay alive lol 

Where I feel this game is a bit lacking is the lore. Playing through this game felt a little bit like reading the second part of a series, where all the worldbuilding has been already explained before and I'm left to try to make a whole from the bits and pieces we get via the narration we get throughout the game. But, hey, maybe this was done on purpose and I just didn't catch on.

Generally speaking, it's a charming title if you're looking for a nostalgic-feeling quick play (it 4 hours exactly to complete the first run), and even after you finish the main plot, you can still spend some time getting all the achievments both within the game and here on Steam. Not the greatest title I've ever played in my life, but definitely one of the best games from the early 2010s! 

--- TL;DR ---
• GRAPHICS: gorgeous and detailed, with a certain watercolor-y feel to them
• GAMEPLAY: pleasant and just the right amount of challenging, the controlls are really really good for an old-ish game
• AUDIO: the music is really nice and fits the general "feel" of the game
• STORY: somewhat lacking--it feels like we're missing the background to fully understand what is happening
• AUDIENCE: 12 and up 
• DIFFICULTY: just the right amount, can be made harder via ingame machanics 
• PRICE: buy on sale 
• PERSONAL SCORE: 6.5/10

A nice little game that I felt didn't overstay it's welcome. I did find the narrator obnoxious and distracting at times when I really needed to focus (it could be turned down, but I never got to that point). It was a little annoying that you were forced to use new weapons - like it was nice that you were encouraged to try  new weapons (and there was usually an Armory or whatever that let you change not long after), but when you have a near upgraded weapon, it was a shock to go to a weaker, non upgraded weapon.

I suppose that didn't matter too much as I found the game on the Easy side (i think I only went down a few times and maybe had 1 full wipe forcing me to restart) though honestly I didn't mind - I like to play long RPGs so something short and easy is a great pallette cleanser.  The end fights especially got pretty easy (I had a near upgraded  Brush Pike and Galleon mortar) which let me kill most in a few hits (and often kill enemies with the mortar outside their range).  That and a lot of health stuff dropped.  It was annoying though to be stuck with a heavy melee weapon for the last few bits - it did 1 hit kills, but it was so slow.

Things were a little clunky at times aiming or trying to walk where I wanted to - I would say most of the few times I got downed was due to this - at one point an enemy (the frog thing) got stuck on me and I was unable to move as other enemies took pot shots at me.

I can't say the story was that impressive (something about the world ended and you were trying to fix it), but I thought the music was good for the most part.

121170835.review:
This is an interesting game to be sure. The game-play is pretty solid, and the story is very intriguing. 

Actually real quick about the story, you have a narrator who talks a lot and informs you of what's going on in the world. It's an interesting concept, but for me it also kind of made me wish this game wasn't set in a post apocalyptic world. The game takes place after some huge Calamity that seemed to have wiped out everyone except for a few survivors. But the narrator spends a good portion of the game telling you about what this world used to be like. Honestly that was so interesting to me that I kind of wish we could have had the game set in THAT world. I think if this company ever thinks about doing a follow up to this game they should consider doing a prequel. I'd love to actually explore this world in it's old state when it was still standing and see some of the concepts the narrator talks about fleshed out more. That is honestly very appealing  to me.

Moving on most everything about the game checks out. You have two weapon slots that you can switch between at anytime, and you can upgrade those weapons to be more powerful. I really like the upgrade system for the weapons as you can choose which upgrades to put on a weapon and you can change them if you don't like them back at your home base. Gives you a lot of incentive to try different things. 

The Alcohol upgrades are also a nice touch, and perhaps a subtle hint that things aren't going well....as you level up you can "equip" more alcohol to give you different bonuses. There are also challenge levels that have you fighting a large group on enemies in an arena like setting for more exp and money, but they also have their own stories attached to them that let you learn a bit more about the world which is nice.

The soundtrack is available as DLC so if you like it feel free to pick it up. All in all this is a good game and I had some fun with it. Like I said I'd actually like to see a prequel of this game where you can interact with the world before the calamity. So hope that comes to pass someday.

120971379.review:
Bastion is a game with no big flaws, but it is also a game that doesn't do anything particularly impressive. It has functional combat, but its not particularly interesting. The visuals look alright, but aren't that great. The story has some interesting ideas, but there's not much to it.

The most interesting thing about Bastion was its narrator. He added a lot of important context and spiced up sections that would otherwise be very bland. The reactiveness to different actions you could take over the course of the game was also good. He was also used very well in the overarching story.

The game has a lot of different weapons available, however it actually feels like there's too many of them. Bastion is a very short game, and with the amount of weapons available there's no way the majority of them will get a significant amount of use. You also can't preview a level before traveling there, so you won't know what weapon you'd want to use for a level before you go, and although there are occasionally opportunities to change weapons mid-level, they're very rare. Since weapons are also upgradeable, you're even more encouraged to use one set of weapons throughout the game, as you won't have the resources to try anything else.

One of the game's gimmicks is that the level assembles/disassembles itself around you as you progress through it. This was introduced as a way to easily tell where you're going, but I had the opposite experience. Being unable to see the path ahead of me until I got close to it made it harder to progress, and I would frequently have to resort walking in a circle around whatever island I was currently on to try and see where the next bridge would assemble itself at.

Overall these aren't major flaws, and the game has stuff going for it. The narrator is good, the music is very enjoyable, and while the gameplay isn't great or very impressive, its fine and hard to be bored by. Maybe Bastion was more groundbreaking back when it first came out.

After finishing Hades, I feared coming back to the first Supergiant's game, because I thought the mechanics wouldn't be as good. Luckily, I was wrong. All this mixed with great visuals and music compositions can really suck you into the apocalyptic world of Bastion and keep you there for hours. Supergiant Games still remains one of my favourite game developer, so I naturally recommend this title with all my heart.

A classic with a brilliant art-style and easy to understand gameplay that manages to have plenty of depth and options despite its ease of understanding. 

The only downsides are that the isometric camera can cause the action to become a bit obscured and frantic, which can be especially frustrating in areas with little floor space, and the weapon upgrade system's tendency to bottleneck you into investing into two early weapons which can be used until the endgame, diminishing some experimentation.

Highly recommended.

118598766.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Being that this is my first playthrough of the game (over a decade after release), I'm really appreciative of the artistic choices made in the game. The visuals nice and timeless in a way that some other games of the era aren't
- The soundtrack is amazing. Sometimes, lyrical tracks in games come off as cheesy or cringey, but all the music here is fantastic. Western vibes with occasional riffing
- The narration is also great. I swore I was listening to Sam Elliot until I looked it up

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- I love that the world comes together as the story unfolds. Nice little thematic unity there
- Other than that, the plot is a little thin. I won't spoil anything, but it wouldn't really matter if I did

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- The controls are excellent. It actually feels "fair" when you get hit
- The weapon diversity and upgrade system are excellent. Because of this, I kinda want to try different builds and maybe do an NG+ someday
- I didn't get into the challenge idol system, but it's there for people who want the challenge/achievements

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- Overall, the game ran well. Also, it doesn't NEED a 4k update, but I'd be really happy if it did

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]8.5/10[/b]. For me, the only thing this was missing was a deep enough story. The combat is excellent, the gear system is nice, and I always appreciate a game that gives you a reason to replay it.

I never really felt in control.

You never make decisions, neither on were to go, nor on what to say.
You are only "a kid" whose story is narrated from the off as you play.

And often you have to use a new weapon. Sure games often do this, but here you can't even decide which of the 2 weapons you can carry, should be switched. Good luck fighting foes from a distance, when your bow is replaced by a machete and your only ranged option is now to throw that bloody thing. Even in new game plus you still have to slog through this parts.


On the other hand the set pieces are gorgeous and diverse.
The difficulty is set with enemy modifications which works really really well, as you can decide before every level what you feel up to right now.
The weapons are all viable and it's only a question of what playstyle one prefers.

117701269.review:
I do think this was a good game, but I'll admit, I think it's a little overrated and I have a hard time recommending it today in 2022.  The game sells itself on the story, which at the time, I believe this was a bit of a pioneer with the narration element, so kudos for that.  But with that said, the narration and storytelling seems to be the only highlight, and even that didn't really feel engaging or terribly clever with its writing.  The combat is simplistic.  The music is good but not monumental.  The graphics were decent (Again, giving it some leeway due to its age).  The controls/mechanics were workable, but not the most intuitive; it felt like I was halfway through the game before I figured out what I was doing.  The challenge was basically non-existent; once I actually figured out how the controls worked, I was effectively at full health AND meds all the time (This was on Normal Mode.  I haven't tried the extra difficulties or New Game+).  All in all, I finished the game in 6.4 hours, not very long.  

In sum, I applaud the developers for their unique approach to storytelling, no pun intended.  I'm looking forward to playing their latter games.  With that said, I don't think the other elements of this game aged well over time. Trying to be generous given its age, I'd give this a 7/10.

115790415.review:
My opinion of this game is definitely an outlier. I found this to be a somewhat mediocre experience. Why? The normal mode felt too easy. The amount of health potion drops seemed very overly generous. Maybe after TUNIC, UNSIGHTED, and Death's Door, I have been conditioned to find more difficulty in games. That said, I don't think I'm off the mark. When you don't bother using resources to get weapon upgrades and still get through the game without having to restart levels, there is something that feels off. I know there is a hard mode and new game+, but other detractors prevented me from wanting this experience to last longer than necessary. I will say that it is nice that there are ways to tailor your difficulty beyond easy, normal and hard mode through one of the buildings. So, you can tailor your difficulty a fair bit more than normal games.

Beyond the lack difficulty of normal mode, I wasn't really fussy on the art style of this game. The environments were fine and it was interesting how it appeared as you walked towards them, but the character designs kind of irked me. The controls felt more clunky after having played other isometric combat games. At first I was thinking, "well, this is a really old indie game" but as my friend pointed out Mario 3 and SMW have great controls and they're much older.

I find it especially weird how this game throws a ton of different weapons, sub-weapons, passive abilities, and upgrades at you. I'm all for variety and this is actually a strength of the game, but it feels weird to have so much variety when the game is so short. I finished it in two sittings and the first sitting wasn't very long. I guess the game figures you'll want to replay it? After the bull shield challenge, I stopped doing all of the weapon challenges. So, I did skip a lot of available content, but I just wasn't really enjoying it that much. That said the weapon challenges are for specific weapons. So, the variety still seems like a lot for a short game.

Positives? Well, as everyone has mentioned, the narrator of the game is great. It's actually nice for a game to throw exposition at you while you're doing stuff in a game, rather than constant cutscenes or having to walk around and talk to people. That was definitely a change of pace. I also thought the music was well done. Not amazing, but it was certainly good. Anyway, I'm sure if you have interest in this game, you've probably already played it by now. If you haven't, your opinion is likely to differ from mine anyway.

114421069.review:
"I dig my hole, you build a wall. But one day that wall is gonna fall."
- Bastion

[h1]💻 Description:[/h1]
A small selection of games has impacted the Indie genre immensely in the past few years, as they introduced new renovating ideas and concepts. Those games were the cornerstone of many small gaming studios, which steadily and progressively climbed mountains towards success. Among these small indie giants, Bastion deserves a leading spot. Being the first-ever title developed by Supergiant Games, this nostalgic adventure not only brings the player back to their childhood years but also offers immense satisfaction, from its flawless combination of beautiful artstyle to its engaging storytelling.

[h1]📖 Setting:[/h1]
[h3]Summary[/h3]
Bastion’s storyline unfolds in a post-apocalyptic world, where the protagonist known as the Kid tries to find any remnants of humanity that survived the aftermath of the Calamity. In hopes of rebuilding the city of Haven for future generations, he embarks on a beautiful adventure with his trusty hammer on his shoulders. Will he be able to find hope in such dark times, only time will tell...

[h3]Narrative[/h3]
At the beginning of the game, Bastion creates an illusion, as the storyline’s main concept seems simple, without following any innovative recipe. Then suddenly, a soothing voice narrates the player’s every step, sharing comments and info related to the story and the protagonist’s background. Logan Cunningham, the narrator of this adventure, creates a unique experience, with quotes that change based on the player’s actions and interactions. The simple addition of such a plain feature generates a beautiful atmosphere which, considering the game’s release date, makes Bastion ahead of its time. 

There are four different story modes that affect how the NPCs interact with the protagonist. It is essential to mention that the player has a certain amount of times they can come back to the spot they died. Once all the chances are used up, the level repeats itself from the beginning.

[table]
[tr]
[th]Name[/th]
[th]Description[/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Normal Mode[/td]
[td]This mode starts a fresh new game. The Levels cannot be revisited.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]No-Sweat Mode[/td]
[td]Starts a new game with unlimited chances to carry on if defeated.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]New Game+[/td]
[td]Upon completing the normal mode, players can start a new adventure with all Structures, Spirits, and Idols unlocked, plus all weapons and XP from the last game.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Score Attack Mode[/td]
[td]It picks ups lost mementoes during a mission, which the player can purchase.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td]Score Attack Mode[/td]
[td]Upon completing the normal mode, players can start a new adventure with all Structures, Spirits, and Idols unlocked; however, it resets the XP bar back to level one. On top of that, levels are repeatable with a scoring system.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1] 🕹️ Gameplay:[/h1]
Lots of detail has been put into the creation of the levels, as well as the combat system. That’s why, gameplay-wise, Bastion is unique. Despite its simplicity, the controls provide a great variety of movements that, combined, generate special skills and different approaches to various situations.

[h3]Level design[/h3]
The shining beacon of Bastion is immediately distinguished in its asymmetric design. The terrain is formed while the player traverses the landscape, a neat feature that gives the game a sense of curiosity. On top of that, there are tons of secrets found in the background that can be easily missed, as most of the time, they are overshadowed by the levels’ charming aesthetics.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830367045
[h3]Combat[/h3]
Through the course of the story, the player will get accustomed to many weapons and mechanics that provide lots of synergistic combinations. The protagonist can carry only two guns, as well as a shield that provides cover. He also has the ability to dodge attacks with a barrel roll, which can be used as many times as he likes. Each weapon opens the door to a variety of special attacks, which in turn can be activated through the use of Black Tonics. Last but not least, health potions can replenish health, but I advise caution since there is a limit to how many the Kid can carry.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830369946
[h3]Progression[/h3]
The main objective of the game is to collect cores. Each level is packed full of enemies and challenges that, upon completion, will provide the necessary shards, from which the core is formed. Various challenges can also be encountered to test the player’s kit and weapon mastery. Those are available on the main map and they mostly reward the player with weapon upgrades, points and exp.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830372502
[b]Collectables[/b]
Through the various corners of the asymmetric environments, the protagonist can find potions that unlock buffs upon consumption, or even weapon pieces, which lead to new upgrades. In addition, each action; from killing an enemy to destroying certain pieces of the environment, offers points that eventually can help the protagonist buy upgrades and various unlockable skills.

[b]The Bastion[/b]
Between levels, the Kid will be able to prepare his kit in his HQ, the Bastion, as it offers all the necessary merchant shops available. Each shop is unlocked automatically while the player progresses the story; however, which of them will be unlocked first, is determined upon individual choice. They can also be upgraded, but that is more of an ending goal.

[h3]Difficulty[/h3]
Thanks to the introduction of the Shrine, players can invoke the power of the Gods, by increasing the difficulty of the game in a variety of ways. In exchange, each invoked god grants a passive boost to XP gain and Fragment drops; the game’s currency. In case the player does not feel challenged enough, the Bastion also provides "Who Knows Where", alternate, dreamlike dimensions, where the Kid can fight off waves of enemies, while the narrator slowly reveals a character's past. 

[h1]👁‍🗨 Visuals:[/h1]
Few things can be said for Bastion’s beautiful hand-drawn animations, as ultimately, they can speak for themselves. Beautiful characters with distinct colours mix well with the vibrant environment of the background, proving why Supergiant Games is the leading player in this department. Jen Zee (art director) made sure to leave her unique touch in this detailed word, a feature worth praise.

[h1]🎧 Audio:[/h1]
Cunningham’s unique acting skills are merging perfectly with the background music, which includes four vocal tunes, as well as many instrumental pieces. Darren Korb (music director) and his crew did a fantastic job in developing a deep emotional connection with all of the characters that personally left me astonished. The sounds are well made, yet at the same time feel lacking, without leaving a strong impact. Nonetheless, I was happy to notice that HD rumble was featured in the game, providing additional immersion. 

[h1]🗃️ Side Notes:[/h1]
Despite its age, Bastion works flawlessly without performance issues. The only nuisance I can think of is in the way the terrain unfolds since it isn’t always clear where its edge is located.

[h1]📋 Verdict:[/h1]
Almost a decade after the game’s original release, Bastion still retains its unique narration, beautiful artstyle and simple gameplay. Everything mixes well together forming a perfect Indie recipe. It is a game that defined my childhood years and I am glad it still maintains its charm.

114254150.review:
[i]Bastion[/i] is a modern classic action game. With a moving story told through solid, simple action gameplay and a host of striking visuals alongside an outstanding soundtrack, this game is an essential PC gaming experience. Lose yourself in this addictive post-apocalyptic landscape as you undertake an unforgettable adventure.

You play as The Kid, a white-haired young man with a knack for dodge rolls and violence. At the behest of an older man named Rucks, The Kid must travel around a ruined land post-Calamity to salvage materials to power the Bastion, a floating island that serves an unclear purpose. Along the way, fight a wide variety of wildlife and machines, collect scraps and mementos from the past society, arm yourself with nearly a dozen different weapons, and build up the Bastion to customize your experience and reassemble what you can of civilization.

The first major release from developer Supergiant Games, most known more recently for the hack-'n-slash roguelike [i]Hades[/i], [i]Bastion[/i] is a game of both gorgeous artistry and excellent gameplay. Combat sequences take up most of the player's time; setpieces spawn throughout levels that players can take on armed with a shield and two weapons of their choice. Enemies have distinct weaknesses to certain weapons, giving levels some replayability down the line as players challenge them outfitted with different equipment. [i]Bastion[/i] also has a decent exploration element, with levels chock full of upgrade materials, mementos that reveal lore, and tons of currency to collect. This currency can be spent in a few ways back at the Bastion, allowing the player to tailor their own experience through the game's dozen or so levels.

[i]Bastion[/i] is a pleasure to witness from the sights and sounds it provides. The game features a number of iconic facets of  art design, ranging from floating level terrain that spawns in virtually underfoot to the soothing-yet-wizened narration of Rucks. With a wide color palatte and level backgrounds bordering on the psychedelic, there's always something good to look at with this one. An outstanding soundtrack compliments the visuals, with songs that match the story's emotional beats and even sporting lyrics corresponding to relevant people or places. Gameplay is enough of a smooth affair that even the less seasoned gamers who simply wish to try this for the story or the aesthetics will find this accessible and rewarding.

Though [i]Bastion[/i] is a decently short adventure, with a full run clocking in at a little over four hours, this game offers players a rich experience with plenty to do. Take on custom challenges to bolster your favorite weapons, fight in arena combat for practice or to experience more of the story, fulfill a host of missions to earn rewards, or further increase the game difficulty with a range of modifiers that amp up the intensity and the rewards. Even this length for a single run is deceptive, as a robust New Game Plus mode can easily bring players back in for a second or third time to tackle completionist objectives or to see what consequences different choices in the story yield.

[i]Bastion[/i] is a mark of excellence for indie gaming. It manages to tell a compelling story with gameplay satisfying to newbies or challenge seekers. Tons of content and replay value, an amazing OST and inspiring world design, simple combat that doesn't get old - there are endless reasons for you to embark on this journey, least of which should be the low sale price this game often goes up for. Play this one as soon as possible. [i]Bastion[/i] gets an A+.

I'm a bit disappointed by how mediocre this game is. The art style is beautiful, but much of the components jumble together where you don't know what's solid ground and what's "background." You have many weapons, upgrades, and skills at your disposal, but only a slight few feel viable. The story tackles serious themes like racism, genocide, cold wars, and mutually assured destruction; but the endings don't really grapple with the personal trauma your character, The Kid, likely experiences.

Aside from the visual art and soundtrack, the only other praise I can give is to the Shrine. The Shrine allows you to customize your difficulty by invoking various gods to strengthen your enemies. In exchange, you get bonus currency and experience. You can alter your experience any time you return to The Bastion, so you're never locked in to your decisions. Ultimately, however, the game doesn't really provide enough viable options to really take advantage of the more difficult options.

113519743.review: This is a really stylish game. The visuals are gorgeous, the music is punchy, the controls are tight, and everything you do is narrated in real time by a gravelly voiced guy just chilling in the background. It's a novel approach to telling the games story that knocked it out of the park for me.  The game itself is pretty short but it tells a somber story about cycles of boom and bust in an imaginative setting and the short runtime makes it really easy to play through in one sitting. If you want more playtime though the build variety is extremely high and NG+ gives the game more replayability than most narrative based games I've played. This is one of my favorite games of all time and I think everyone especially those interested in novel storytelling, or western fantasy aesthetics should play it.

Brilliant game. Definitely deserves the overwhelmingly positive/very positive reviews. Combat was fun, if a bit janky at times, and I could see it getting a bit old and boring in a longer game. Speaking of, the game is quite short. That short time really was thoroughly enjoyed though. Moreover, I felt its length perfectly suited the story being told.

Where the game really shines I feel is through the story, its characters, and the world building. I was fully invested in the world and characters right from the outset, and there wasn't a moment when this dwindled. I was desperate to learn every scrap I could about the situations the characters found themselves in and their backstories. Even now, I'm still wishing for more. The world was just so damn convincing! I don't know how else to explain it. Perhaps that won't be quite as exciting a prospect for some, but for someone who is highly into the character and roleplaying side of any RPG, it really did win me over.  Having the entire tale be narrated really was a great way to learn about the world and such too. I've never seen that before in a game, so it certainly sets Bastion apart in that regard.

113339566.review:
Bastion is a great action game with wonderful presentation and a wide variety of weapons to experiment with.

The combat mechanics are the game's main strength. You unlock many different weapons as you progress through the game, and not only do they each handle differently, they also all tend to actually be fun to use in their own way. They become even more fun to use as you upgrade them, allowing you to give them special abilities (like lighting enemies on fire) or buffing their stats (like increased critical hit chance and damage). Combat remains fun and engaging from beginning to end.

It is worth it to explore the nooks and crannies of the levels, as you can find materials that will allow you to upgrade weapons, as well as currency and experience. While you can't go back to levels you've beaten to find things you missed, in a nice touch whatever items you missed will end up in the "Lost & Found" where you can buy them with the currency you've accumulated. This way you can't accidentally lock yourself out of being able to upgrade any particular weapon. You also gain access to a variety of special moves (many linked to specific weapons), as well as optional buffs you can equip to suit your play style. Eventually you even gain the ability to make the game more difficult by buffing the enemies. The more buffs you stack, the greater the money and experience you gain from them (although I would have liked to see greater benefits considering how much more difficult using this system makes the game). There are also "Proving Grounds" for each weapon, challenging your prowess with each weapon in exchange for rewards. Some of these were surprisingly easy, while others seemed darn near impossble without first powering up the weapon to its maximum level and selecting specific power-ups.

The presentation is also great, with one caveat. I love the vibrant and colorful worlds and the way they "assemble" from fragments of land that ascend from below to form the terrain as you explore it. The music is also quite good, with a Western influence that gives the game a unique feel. The Western influence extends to one of Bastion's more recognizable gimmicks: One of the in-game characters narrates everything that happens as it's happening, giving you plot details and offering commentary on your actions and discoveries. While this is an ambitious creative choice that often impressed me (I like how you get commentary based on what combination of weapons you've chosen to take into battle), it's also distracting when you're getting an exposition dump at the same time an intense battle is taking place. This is especially egregious in the "Who Knows Where" areas, where you're intended to get backstory on some of the game's main characters but for the life of me I just couldn't follow the narration and the combat at the same time. At several parts in the game I would find myself tuning out the narration altogether, to the point where I couldn't really give you an accurate idea of what the plot is about. But maybe that's just me!

Bastion is a great game with engaging combat and unique presentation. Recommended.

Bastion has aged well and I believe will continue to do so. The main story excluding challenges will take the player around 4 hours on the normal mode (I did the challenges myself, however I played quite quickly). 112429896.review:
When a studio like Supergiant Games goes on to make one of the greatest games of all time, Hades, I felt like I had to pay homage to their first developed game: Bastion. Playing Bastion, it was easy to see the building blocks for the future masterpiece: The combat style, the array of weapons, and the mountain of thought and care put into the script itself.
	What Bastion does right is several things. I’d like to start with my favorite aspect of the game: the narration and story. “The Stranger” follows us the player, “The Boy”, while giving us a hindsight angle on the happenings, as if telling a story over a campfire or a good drink. You’d think that someone talking over a majority of the game may get old, but every time you hear that voice, you want to hear what he’s going to say, and he never disappoints. The story itself works well with the game’s short playtime, which left me satisfied yet ready for more the game may throw me if I decide to replay with NG+. There were a handful of “wow” moments that will stick with me for a long time, where my choices felt impactful in the best kinds of ways.
	My second favorite aspect of the game is the combat. With the array of weapons and skills to choose from, choosing your favorite 2-weapon plus skill combo is no easy choice. I myself ended up with a short-ranged main weapon along with a long-ranged secondary, and an aoe skill. While I felt like the feel of the combat was there, sometimes it left something to be desired, perhaps spoiled by the perfection Supergiant rose to in Hades. With that said, the formula is still there and resulted in very rewarding gameplay, along with leaving me having several great moments.
	Before I talk about my last minor gripe with the game, I would also like to call out the music of this game. I’ll admit I had listened to some of it prior to playing this game, but boy, in addition to some songs I missed, hearing them in context just made them so much better. I will for sure be visiting them again, and soon.
	My last major gripe with the game is also a boon to it, which may sound oxymoronic but I feel like I cannot review the game accurately without voicing it. I have a gripe with part of the core design of the game – the ‘rebuilding’ of the game’s maps. While I agree it adds charm to the game, it honestly felt unnecessary at times. And while I could have missed an explanation, I ended the game with uncertainty if it was actually happening in the game’s canon or simply a design choice. 
	At the end of it all, this is still a great game that managed to do a whole lot in its short playtime, which I would recommend any big fan of Hades or of the genre overall to do a playthrough of to further appreciate Supergiant’s growth. 8/10

111847487.review:
Review based on Graphics, Story, Gameplay, Steam Achievements and other noteworthy things to mention:

Graphics:
Average graphics, especially for a game people would now consider "old". The game art in general, is quite nice, cheacters looks very short and cute, almost chibi-style. The game doesn't have any animated cut-scenes, instead they are portrayed through still pictures of scenes. 

Story:
Took me a while to get my head around the story because it takes place in a world rich in lore and your game starts in the middle of it. I personally didn't find the story intriguing but you can tell the game developers spent time curating a believable fantasy world, and I appreciate it.

Gameplay:
Top down, action role-playing. You can choose your mix-match of weapons, powerup tonics, weapon enhancemements and even "idols" (which make the game more difficult but in return yield more XP and money). Your character doesn't speak and much of what is said is done through a narrator (of another character you meet early in the game). I like that the world and levels in this game are creatively designed on floating tiles that either fall away or rise up around you as you walk around but this makes falling down a risk, as you don't die but without a certain tonic in place, you'll end up taking damage when you spawn again. I'd describe the game as easy because on a simple play through it's easy to power up your weapons and abilities and end up really overpowered by the end of the story, though the other modes and getting the achievements can be quite brutal...which leads onto...

Steam Achievements: This took me about 50+ tries to get 100% on several levels. Most importantly, you have to complete the game a minimum of about 2 times, and then up to level 2 on Score Attack Mode. The hardest achievement for me was the "About the Author" achievement, where even watching it done through a guide and trying myself, I ended up having to redo it 50+ times to get it perfect. But all achievements are attainable with enough patience, practice and time; and thankfully, not as skill dependant as achievements for other games (this is because enemies in Bastion spawn randomly and sometimes, if you're lucky they'll spawn far away from you or in the line of sight of a turret you laid down).

Other:
This game has replay value in both the steam achievement hunting and also because there are multiple possible endings. There are plenty of weapon combinations and stuff for you to try out on later run-throughs too! 
I did not like the narration honestly. No offence to the voice actor (who has a splendid voice), but the script had some very corny one-liners in it. It sounded like every sentence had to be cool or quotable but it offered no personality or enhancement to the story. 
There were a few bugs I encountered, none of them game breaking but pretty much involved restarting the stage all over again.
I would reccommend people play the game because overall, I enjoyed it on my first run through. It's not the usual type of game I'd buy or play but this one has made me feel like I am missing out on other good games in the genre.

Bastion is a beautiful game. I do admit that I found it difficult to keep up with the story at times because they deliver it to you while you are in combat and focusing on other things, but I got enough to really appreciate the effort put into this game.

110600049.review:
This is a narrative-driven game is which you control a nameless protagonist (known only as the Kid) fighting through the world to collect a series of Macguffins to deal while an mysterious Calamity while a voiceover narrates everything that happens. The narration feels like an odd choice at the beginning of the game when everything he says seems obvious, but ultimately you learn much more about the world and what has happened to it through what the Narrator chooses to tell you and how he describes various events. The main story itself is fairly short. taking me only about 10 hours to complete, but it is well-told and builds up to a satisfying conclusion.

The bulk of the gameplay consists of learning how to master the variety of weapons you acquire during the course of the main story. The game includes a series of challenges focused around each weapon, as well as a couple of long optional challenges ("dreams") which provide backstory on each of the major characters. A small amount of content only appears in New Game Plus or Score Attack modes, but the main story does not change. 9/10

109780981.review:
I came to this game expecting more Hades-like gameplay with a new story, given that people seem to recommend playing this game if you liked playing Hades, but instead what I got was a watered-down version of Hades in pretty much every aspect, and no story.

The combat:
Feels slow because your character moves pretty slowly, lacks variety because you're locked into two weapons (that you can switch between missions) which have 1-2 attacks each, and a special move that you can only use 3 times before needing to be refilled with more uses by consumables you find. Weapon upgrades are standard "do more damage" or "have a chance to crit", paling in comparison to the Daedelus hammers and weapon aspects in Hades, which can significantly change the weapon and how you use it. In general there's a lack of "punch" to the combat; more often than not, killing enemies feels unsatisfying, they just die and it feels like nothing.

The story and characters:
You have a homebase that you can build stuff into, using things called "cores" that you find from missions that you fly into from your homebase. That's the "story" I guess, because there's barely any characters in this game from what I saw, basically just your player character (whose name I don't know, if he even has one), a stranger in your homebase who's also the narrator apparently, and the enemies, which look much the same, but the narrator sometimes describes as characters of sorts. A far cry from the memorable cast of characters in Hades, essentially.

The graphics:
Sometimes pretty, sometimes too much clutter on the screen, but generally the best aspect of the game. That said, again, Hades is also better in this aspect, but even if Bastion had better graphics, Hades has the better gameplay, and to me, gameplay and story is more important than pretty graphics. If I can have both, fantastic, if not, don't focus so much on just graphics, just make sure they're consistent and prioritize gameplay being fun.

Overall:
The one hour I spent playing the game felt one of the longest hours I've ever spent playing a videogame; the slow-moving character and the clumsy-feeling controls put me off pretty quickly already, but I kept pushing forward in the hopes of finding a good story and maybe growing to like the combat, yet after completing a few missions that felt much the same and had no real story to speak of, I concluded that it's unlikely that the game would suddenly change drastically for the better. In comparison, Hades felt great to play from the very beginning, and there was an actual story with interesting characters.

Sure, Bastion is a decade old game at the time of writing this, but even if this was 2011 and we had no Hades to compare to, I would much rather play a game like Diablo 2, which at the time of Bastion's release was also a decade old game, because it did all of the above better than Bastion (minus maybe the graphics in terms of prettiness). Just play Hades instead of this, or find something else if you're bored of Hades.

Rating:
5/10 - technically not a bad game (it functions, didn't seem to have any bugs etc), but why would you play this, when there are far better games out there?

109730659.review:
An amazing first game by Supergiant Games. 
The story follows the Kid and his journey to restore the Bastion and discover what the Calamity has transformed the new world into. The characters are pretty decent while it could be argued that there isn't really any characterisation or that much voice acting in the game, i think the use of Rucks being the narrator of the game is really well used as he goes into many topic matter such as the actions of the Kid, the history of the different locations that you will venture etc, and it just makes the game that much enjoyable from a narrative standpoint. The story itself is pretty interesting as there are many things revealed to the player and also many mysteries that leaves a lot for the player to come up with their own conclusions. While it may look like a simple restore the world and betrayal type of plot, Bastion has much more intense and thought provoking themes within its structure that players will soak up and enjoy. 
The setting that this game takes place in is well developed and each level is distinct in its own way from one another. There are areas such as mines, city markets, dense jungles, crystal labyrinths etc that are all presented in the games beautiful design and makes them feel mystical and apocalyptic, giving the game its own image to stand out from the other indie titles out there.
Visually, its really beautiful and unique. All of the character and enemy designs are really well detailed and the areas that i had mentioned before are very distinct and where completely different from any game that was released in 2011. The art style is done in a fantasy painting esque that is really satisfying to look at. Thankfully, Supergiant games has stuck with this style and have interpreted it to each new game that they have developed. 
The sound and audio are extremely impressive with the soundtrack being able to go in all directions possible and still being able to pull off each and every style that it attempts, to the audio of enemies, weapons and even the simplest of things like selecting tonics or gods being on point and sounding that they fit perfectly in the world that Supergiant have developed. 
In terms of gameplay, its really impressive, especially coming from (at the time) a new indie development team. The only nit pick i will say and get out the way immediately is the fact that i think that combat can be a bit too basic, but the game does have means for the player to be given a challenge. You'll have your standard actions such as roll, melee attack, ranged attack, super attack etc, but the game elevates this by giving the player so many options as to approach combat. The array of weapons that are provided in game is really impressive and allows the player to mix and match between them to give them their most preferable play style. These weapons can also be upgraded by using the in came currency and certain items that can be found or bought. Each upgrade that a weapon can get can be switched around to give the player even more versatility in terms of gameplay. There are tonics that are used as perks in the game and just like the weapon upgrade system, each time you level up you can have another slot to add another tonic. This allows for players to mix and match perks in what order suits them. There is a shrine where the player can carry out and complete achievements in return for currency. I mean the list goes on for what this game has to offer such as enemy buffs the player can put on in exchange for xp and reward boosts, items shop, weapon challenges to unlock new special abilities etc. This game has it all and makes itself accessible to anyone who interested in playing. Finally, the game offers many modes as to play the game such as new game plus, a round based mode and so on. 
Overall, Bastion was a brilliant start to Supergiant Games's catalogue and i would 100% recommend this to anyone wanting an amazing RPG/beat em up with and engaging story, beautiful visuals and a breath taking soundtrack.

109160697.review:
TL;DR: its a good short game go play it if you liked hades

I've been interested in playing this game ever since I finished Hades, as I really enjoyed it and the clips I saw of Bastion looked like it had similar gameplay aspects. Recently played this game since my friend gifted it to me and I was not disappointed at all. If we are comparing this game to Hades, I do feel that Hades is still the better game, but that is kind of a given, considering that Bastion is the first game Supergiant made and Hades was a result of everything they learnt from making this, Transistor and Pyre. If you liked Hades though, I do feel you would like this game as the gameplay is quite similar and it has a nice story. 

The game is very short, as you can finish the game in about 7 hours (I played through new game plus so my time is about twice that length), with the game being comprised of short areas you traverse through to progress the story, so you can just hop on and play at anytime basically. I think this is the part where I gush over the gameplay, as I really liked the gameplay. The combat, while again not as good as Hades, is very fun, as the environment and movement options allow you to use different approaches to various situations. You also get a wide variety of weapons throughout the game, which you can upgrade by collecting the specific material for that weapon or buying it, then buying the upgrade. This allows for a variety of differing playstyles, all of which are fun to just try out. To try them out or grind for money, there are arenas in the bastion where you can fight wave after wave of enemies. These arenas or dreams also give you backstories/a better look at the personalities of the characters in the game which I think is a brilliant way to tell a story.

Speaking of characters, the characters are very well developed in my opinion considering the amount of screentime they get. Excluding Rucks, who narrates the entire game, there are also Zulf and Zia, who you meet as you progress through the story. These two dont get much screentime as you wont spend too much time in the Bastion with them, but I feel like their characters were actually explored well considering that. 

The OST of this game is also very nice, as some of the tracks really does hit you in the feels and fit with the narratives and characters very well. Overall, very solid game. Dont expect this to be as good as Hades, but you can clearly see the amount of growth Supergiant has gone through over the years.

109145167.review:
Bastion es un juego hermoso, el juego cuenta con escenarios pintados a mano que te asombra en cada momento que lo estas jugando, aunque a veces confunde este mapeado, ya que Bastion el escenario cae del cielo y en un baile hipnótico se va formando ante ti, aunque hermoso tambien es lioso, ya que muchas veces confunde tu sentido comun en el camino logico del mapa.

El combate de Bastion es muy entretenido ya que Bastion cuenta con un arsenal demasiado grande para su duracion, hay armas de todos los tipos y me parecio genial lo diferentes que son cada una de la otra, esto crea muchas formas diferentes de comportarse en cada batalla, haciendolas muy diferentes dependiendo de que decidas llevarte a la batalla, aunque tambien es cierto que a mi me parecio que el ultimo arma que vas desbloqueando es la mas idonea para la zona en la que te encuentras, siendo las ultimas armas las mejores, al menos para mi.

La historia del juego es entretenida, nada para tirar cohetes pero siempre quise saber que rayos sucedia y cuando termino el juego todo hizo click de una manera muy brillante, ademas de la historia el juego cuenta con un narrador, que al principio me molesto, pero luego viendo que tenia dialogos para tantos escenarios y situaciones le comence a coger cariño y a gustarme.

El juego cuenta con coleccionables, brebajes y materiales de mejora, haciendo estos que de una u otra forma tu personaje vaya mejorando cada vez, dado esto la dificultad del juego no es elevada incluso usando el sistema de altares del juego, que potencian la dificultad del juego agregandole caracteristicas extra a los enemigos.

La musica es buenisima!, y en la recta final si te sentias en un evento importante, porque la musica te lo pone asi.

Bastion es un excelente juego, cortito, disfrutable, muy bonito a la vista, con excelente musica y dificultad moderada, a pesar de los años sigue siendo muy entretenido.

I hate this game... I'm just fooling. XD

I'll be honest. Bastion is a great game! Another one of the list of my favorite games. The visual artwork, the gameplay mechanics, the soundtracks, and most of all, the storyline. The game is almost perfect because you may encounter little or no bugs/glitches. Can play on any age. There's even a leaderboard that you can score your way to the top if you want to. Hunting for achievements' kinda easy, and aiming 'Hard Bargain' for Score Attack Mode isn't too hard, as long as your skilled enough. 

It may be an indie, but this deserves as a Triple-A game. There's no way that most players would not recommend this game because of it's huge success, and more than 100 awards is the proof that this decade old game is still the best.

I highly recommend this game to all players, especially to those who played the game Hades. Promise, you won't regret it. If you can't afford it, buy it on sale!

I'll give this game two thumbs up and a 100/10 rating.

108332114.review:
Amazing game. I've completed 100% of its achievements, which requires 2 full playthroughs and 1 NG+ playthrough.

The story, the ambience, the music, and especially the Narrator, make this game a very unique experience, where you get pulled into the story slowly without realizing it. It shows that it is carefully crafted in every aspect.

There are several game modes available:
- Standard will make this game a challenging and fun experience, albeit frustrating at times just like any other challenge.
- No-sweat mode is great for people who want to experience the story and remove the frustration of restarting a level when dying.
- New Game Plus starts you off with the upgrades obtained in the previous playthrough, and unlocking several new bonuses. You will feel powerful, be able to try different builds, and challenge yourself in more interesting ways.
- Score Attack mode is overall a different experience, and I'd say it's a good endgame once you've learnt everything there is about this game. You start from the beginning, with the option to unlock stuff in any order you want, but you still have to progress through the game. Each level is now repeatable and has a score counter that works through killstreaks and combos, enabling you to compete for high-scores.

The game is quite short, but it has more replayability than the majority of games of its same genre. Highly recommended.

Boring grind fest. So I will place here a recipe for huckleberry pancakes instead.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside.  In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs.  Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the  best job).  Fry at 400 degrees.  Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown.  Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).

107450360.review:
I'm usually not a big fan of isometric shooters, but I really liked that one. It kept a lot of things simple, such as resource managment (you only have health potions and charges for your special attack) and whatever weapon you chose, you had a ground layer of mechanics that you always had and always functioned the same, namely the dodge roll and the shield to reflect attacks. Yet the weapons allowed you to adjust whatever playstyle you had, with melees having different ranges and speeds aswell as partially ranged capabilities, and the actual ranged weapons didn't try to be a full upgrade of one another, but rather sidegrades, with each weapon having a pretty unique ability (apart from the repeating ones, those did kinda feel samey).

The level design is also well-made and you'll most likely enjoy every bit of it, and as you progress, you will notice a tonal shift according to the story, which is also great to experience. There are some secrets hidden here and there, but they are never impossibly well hidden, you just need to explore a little to find them.

The story itself is also amazingly well done. It starts out slow, but as you progress, the story gets more "personal" as what you hear is not only what has happened, but also what you have seen and what you did. It doesn't feel like there are any bad moments in the story, and it's never super shoved in your face, which is also nice.

The only gripes are these:
[list]
[*] once you completed areas, you can't go back. This feels a bit bad, as I often felt I had to explore everything to not miss out on such, causing me to lose health and time.
[*] while it's easy to hit bigger objects laying on the ground, smaller floating objects were much harder to hit. I never got a good feel as to where I need to aim for, as both the shadow as well as the body itself didn't reliably do the trick.
[*] sometimes it's hard to tell what is background and what is actual ground, so I did fall on occasion, however I want to stress that this is the rare exception than the norm.
[/list]

Overall, a great game, and for that price you can't go wrong, especially since it does have a great replayability value.
