106866342.review:
[h1] Review[/h1] 
Now Bastion is a classic. When the game came out it was coupled with various steam events, including having later the main voice actor of this game as an announcer in Dota 2. It’s one of these games where you can’t really make up your mind on it when you only play it once due to its gameplay systems.

[u]Gameplay[/u]
As an action-adventure from a top-down perspective it has the usual abilities, small stat increases, and weapon upgrades. Generally, it plays rather bland as the game will give you a new weapon almost every level. These levels usually benefit using these weapons in one way or another but, especially when doing arena fights, it becomes obvious which weapons are good and which are completely useless.  Often in these type of games the combat is the best, here its totally fine but you mostly play it for the story.

The map design also doesn’t play into the games favour, as I would say that random floating objects in the sky make for a cool concept they aren’t as fun as they seem to be. A lot of the maps become rather bland and due to the more isometric top down camera the whole perspective doesn’t work that well when being forced to walk narrow paths in a really weird perspective. This makes some people even rage quit as you will fall a lot down and get damage. This can be managed.

Hitboxes can be weird. You can automatically or manually aim. The first isn’t always optimal as it will always aim at the person closest to you not the one with the lowest hp or any other priority you might need. Another example is the broken blocking system. In order to block you need to lock onto a target as moving with the mouse isn’t a thing. This is awful if you try to block things, but an enemy is directly in front of you the protagonist will make a 360 and just get himself hurt.

This made the gameplay rather average. Bland. In itself its not something you really get for its gameplay as there are more well thought out games in this genre.

[u]Story[/u]
Now the reason the game stood out was less because its story itself but rather how it is presented. The story is told by a person who basically comments on everything. And due to the writing, it works very well giving the game a depth that it didn’t have before. The storyteller sometimes addressed the player indirectly, especially when talking about the main character as a kid who is a young adult which fits to me as I played the game when I was rather young.

Initially its quite curious what’s going on. The story is told weird, additionally some things are never explained. But in the end, it comes to a good conclusion that didn’t left me disappointed. Its less character driven and more narrative driven, quite literally.
It’s a story that cant really be told by books or movies so it sets itself apart and has its own validation for existing.

[u]Sound[/u]
The game got an interesting repertoire of tracks. Additionally, it fits into the narrative as well as the game not only has its combat and ambient tracks but also some which feature vocals that the game even addresses at some point giving and playing into the established lore.

[u]Graphics[/u]
Its quite interestening that they managed to make a game blend three types of graphical artstyles neatly into each other. As in the background the game features still images that picture aren’t really possible to make out that well featuring distant landscapes. Ontop of that you have the regular paths the main character is walking around, which are static drawings but they appear from time to time and also have a 2.5 dimensional perspective so to say. You character on the other hand is completely 3D .

[u]Conclusion/TL;DR[/u]
I think its not such a great game as people makes it out to be but it is very memorable solely for its presentation, story, narrative and soundtrack. There are reasons you should play this game but its totally understandable if people dislike it because of its gameplay.

Above average ARPG

106336278.review:
One of the best games ever made IMO.

It combines amazing soundtrack and music with sharp make-your-own-style shooter gameplay where every loadout is viable, and you can improve upon what you like to use. The narrator of the game is phenomenal, so much so that you want to do stupid things to see how he'll respond. The overall story of the game is also great, slowly uncovering what happened in the world as a player, even if the character that is played knows all about it already.

The more you interact with the game, the more the game pays off in a narrative and gameplay sense. You can make the game harder for yourself, or undertake difficult challenges, and not only will the narrator comment about it (as he is wont to do), you will get some unique rewards for doing so. The level design is always unique and carefully hand crafted, so every level is its own experience, either gameplay-wise or narrative-wise.

It's an amazing game, and if you've never played it, you're doing yourself a disservice.

106309326.review:
So, I am not usually somebody who makes reviews, but this is my 2nd ever review on Steam for a game I believe is worth the review and should get a little more praise. I am not someone who takes apart games by its littlest detail. So I will just review over my impressions of the game and how it over all made me feel. After all, if a game made you feel something and got you really thinking, then the game did its job right? 

I tend to be a pretty bad game hopper, so it was only recently that I decided to finally start going down my steam list, one by one. This was the very first game on my list and boy, was it an amazing start to that decision. 
-------

As a disclaimer: This is not my first SuperGiants game, my very first was HADES, and I can say that I loved HADES (Switch Port) so much, that I just needed to get and play all of the other SuperGiant games. Little did I know that Bastion was their very first game and man, I wish it was longer because it's a wonderful experience. 

Gameplay/Genre/Combat: It works very similarly to Hades actually, go figure its the same company. However, there are some differences! You have a lot more weapons to choose from, you can wield two weapons (For an example, my main weapon is the hammer and my secondary are the Duel Pistols), and you have a Secret Skill or technique. You can only have one Secret Skill at a time and every time you activate it, it takes away a Black Potion which allows you to use the skill. You have a certain amount of healing potions and black potions but can pick them up as you go. Along with THOSE potions, you are given a different set of potions. Every time you level up, a new slot for a new potion is added to your Distillery. You can apply them to your character as a boost while you play the game. Each one has a certain ability like being able to do +25% Damage when you Counter as an example. You can dodge roll and you can even block with a shield! The game-play itself is a rouge-like action role-play, so it is very quick, its a little slow at the beginning, but once you get used to it you become a speed demon! If you want to give yourself a challenge, you can invoke the gods in the game at the shrine which allows the enemies to be stronger, faster, damage resistant and much more. It's very crafty and clever for their very first game, you can feel the HADES similarities if your first game was HADES. If THIS is your first SuperGiant game, then I can say that its a smooth ride from this game to the next one.

Music and Art: Stunning, the composer for this game (Darren Korb) is the same man who did HADES and I think he is THE composer for SuperGiant. He is just amazing at bringing the game to life, the music is fantastic and I cant help but groove to it every time. The art is also stunning, (Made by Jen Zee) there is always beauty and intricacy to every small detail, it is all 3D models to a 2D made background and I love the artistic visuals and views that this artist puts into the game. The music and art blend together beautifully, along with the game-play and movement make a very easy, yet a challenging, and fun experience. Very pleasing to the eyes and the ears.

Story: The story is short and sweet but also bitter sweet at the same time. I wont get too far into it, I don't want to spoil anyone. The story is something you put together over time, the narrator is telling a story to you, about The Kid (you), the other people you meet, the world you find yourself in, the weapons you acquire and much more. The more mementos (items in the areas you land in after the world broke into pieces) you find, the more you get to learn about the culture's that used to be there and so on. It is a short but yet sweet story of destruction, loss and desperation, But also hope, growth, and home. 

Characters: They are all wonderful, over time you get used to the narrator speaking over your game as you learn more. Not to spoil too much, my favorite character is the Survivor, as I am a very hopeful person to people like him. They all have their own individual stories that you can go through if you pick up their specific mementos and belongings. You get to learn about how they grew up and how they ended up where they are now. How SuperGiant executes interacting with the characters is wonderful, I just wish you were able to interact with them more than just approaching them with certain items. But they go through their own smaller character arcs.

Leveling: It is slow. But worth the small grind! As you go through the areas again and again you will level up, and when you do, you get to unlock a new potion slot. The potion spot at the Distillery allows you to   have potions that make you stronger and more beefy as you defeat enemies and go through the story, or to help make achievement hunting easier! 

Over-all Conclusion: It is amazing, absolutely wonderful, I truly believe so far that SuperGiant games does not miss when it comes to their games. They put a lot of thought and passion into what they make as an indie company and their games should be given more of a chance outside of the ground breaking Hades. Hades is a lot more open ended, no matter how many times you die you will always get new story progression and there is a lot you can do in the game. Bastion is shorter, a little more linear, and focuses on story, but even after 1 full play-through, I still have not maxed everything or tried everything and I hope to! But again I say that SuperGiant games does NOT miss, it only hits!

So try it out, you may end up falling deeper in love with these guys just like I have!

106185365.review:
It's rare to come across a game that packs such a narrative wallop that plays over such a short time, but it's all there, and in spades. Loneliness, grief, revenge, betrayal, hope, and (maybe) forgiveness, all of them your companion as you travel through Bastion's world, watching it, quite literally, rise and fall with each step. Every step takes you closer to a slowly-unveiling existential crisis that you just can't stop marching towards. The ending(s) stays with you for days.

The narration and music are, as many have pointed out, perfect. 

The game-play offers some replay value/flexibility, what with multiple endings (all of which have their own significance), various weapon combinations—each with their own set of toggle-able skills (though you'll likely settle for either personal favorites or community-source over-powered combinations)—shrines with double-edged boosts and handicaps, and a variety of challenges.

Overall, highly recommended, and truly deserving of all of its awards. Be reminded of what a good game is and should be.

105992516.review:
More of a middle thumb to be honest...
I did play Hades first so I'm not sure if that influenced my experience, I have a feeling it did.

Definitely well made, great art, beautiful music, the narration was well done even though I did find it got annoying pretty quickly and ended up turning it off and read the subtitles instead; the writing was solid. A creative world where the tiles create themselves under your very feet...full of light and colour, just an overall well constructed game. However, despite its beauty I found it to not be overly enjoyable. It started with the combat; it's passable but not very fun; you might find otherwise but just could not get into it the way I did with Hades. Rolling off the level, weird quirky enemies, not hitting things when you think you will, and a few crashes didn't enhance my playthrough. Particularly the ranged weapons were underwhelming. I unlocked everything and all the upgrades which helped things a bit by then I was just eager to get it over with. I played a New Game+ and was even more eager to finish it up. On a sale it may be worth exploring Supergiant's first title for 'historical' reasons but if you've already played Hades and are looking for another similar game to play this is not it. 

TLDR; 
6.5/10

105619650.review:
Supergiant's first game, you wouldn't think their first game would be so good but man Bastion is fantastic. 

If you haven't played a Supergiant game, their games are usually isometric action games with light RPG elements and fantastic visuals and laid back vibes and good storytelling. Bastion in particular is really cool because it's story is told through a narrator, he's a character you will meet in the game who's there and narrates the entire game, even some moves you do or when you mess up or get hit he will always have something to say and it's pretty engaging.
I really have no complaints about this game at all, I loved the combat and I think the levels were perfect in length. I like the new game plus and the amount of combat options there is, it's pretty in depth and you get to choose the way you want to play the game but it doesn't feel complicated like other games. You wouldn't think this is a game from 2011 because it still feels very modern to play.

Bastion is considered an indie classic for a reason, it's a really great game and holds up very well even now. It took me way too long to finally get around to playing it but I'm glad I did.

103280924.review:
"A game where your actions are narrated to you."
Seeing this, the first thing I was doing was throwing myself off the edge of every single map to see what new dialogue there was.

You play as 'the kid' who has to get these cores to power up the Bastion which gives you new stores/things to upgrade. While picking up new weapons, killing new enemies, gives you flavour dialogue everywhere. Even in the upgrades menus, which I found quite bizarre but it was welcoming. I didn't know this until about an hour in, but clicking 'INFO' when hovering over things in the map gives you even more narrator dialogue. Fancy. It's not so much a big component as it is a very nice touch, and just the way most of the plot is delivered. A few small meta jokes but nothing major. Though the fact that most fluff was delivered through voice, in a game of this genre, did make me want to see it all.

The challenges that earn you certain rewards can also be quite difficult. That's not a bad thing, of course. Though the rest of the game is pretty easy in comparison. Generally, these are best done if you really want/need the bonuses. The Third Prize(, usually an upgrade item,) is practically given to you for each challenge finished. Upgrades tend to make these challenges easier, of course. 
Speaking of challenges, Who Knows Where was a neat little addition with different backstories, a good few places to grind for the currency used for buying stuff. The only drawback is having to redo all the waves, even if completed before. Beating each Who Knows Where the first time is worth it, but I wouldn't replay them. The game tends to give you enough to get by without repeating them.

Another little nice thing is the dynamic music. It's very subtle in some cases, obvious in others, but adds a nice touch. I've always loved music with different tracks, that fade in and out depending on what's going on or due to a trigger.

As for the story (Spoilers, but I'll do my best to avoid them) the final two ending choices kind of threw me off guard a little bit. Don't get me wrong, I was genuinely invested, and when the choice menus popped I seriously had to think about both of them. The backstory through Who Knows Where was something I found myself wanting to explore too. Especially with the little trinkets you find throughout the game, showing them to each character and seeing what they have to say.

This game, like Transistor, also has a NG+ mode. While I'm not really interested in playing through at the moment, I'll certainly replay it again at some stage. I put this game off for a while, but when I got into it I really enjoyed it.

102792100.review:
Bastion is fantastic story driven game, which slowly unfolding through excellent narration and sublime 2D artstyle. It's really fun when narrator really comments on every of your actions, like early on when getting a weapon, I've decided to smash containers, for a while, being rewarded by shot quip, that instead of moving on "I've decided to rage a little". Quite funny and unique. 
Nothing really spells the end of times  like world that is fragmented and keeps collapsing and forming right as you travel through it. Story is simple but well told, characters are few but you grow to care about them, Conclusion of the story leaves you with a singular profound choice, and a hope that we don't every cause such a calamity.
Music is just superb, I rarely notice it in games, but no game is complete without it, with supergiant games you are just unable to miss it. Combat music that clearly inspired by western movies as well as EDM beats, and few beautiful songs that will just make you stop and listen.

Gameplay is basic is clearly second to story telling here. It is far from perfect but acceptable.
You have isometric combat with doge block and parry mechanic, and you can bring two weapons to the fight out of sizable array of melee and ranged options. Progression offers variety of upgrades to the weapon arsenal and some tasty liquors as passives buffs to your character.
It's all rather simple but fine for a shorter title. 
Game is rather easy initially but you can adjust difficulty of the game on the fly by use of God Totems, that will disadvantage you quite heavily but offer bonus xp. Curse out the gods, and hope for the best. 

I really loved the slow narration and atmosphere of the game, unique mix of postapocaliptic fantasy with a western references, it was a good experience.

Can't help myself not to bring Hades, supergiant clearly felt like bastion is something they couldn't really do justice by 10 years ago. So many elements of Bastion gameplay were perfected in Hades. It's almost like Hades was an indirect sequel or Bastion a blueprint for an outstanding game, that checked all the boxes.

Somos un pibito alcohólico que se la pasa durmiendo y aterriza con la napia cada vez que comienza un nuevo nivel. ¿Por qué digo que aterriza? Porque no se sabe como, pero todo el mundo está hecho concha. Pedazos de porciones de tierra flotando por todos lados... Ah! y todos muertos. Va, no todos. Nos vamos a ir encontrando nuevos amiguis que nos van a ir acompañando en nuestra aventura para salvar el mundo y reconstruir todo. ¿Re básico no? Sí, pero está bien hecho y es humilde. Es el primer juego de un par de flacos que saben de jueguitos y se nota el cariño que le pusieron.
El apartado artístico es hermoso y cuco, salvo por ahí el modelo del protagonista que desentona un toque con el resto. Los bichitos están bien.
La musiquita está copada. Hay un narrador que nos va contando que pasa y no rompe las bolas, aunque puede llegar a desconcentrar un poco cuando nos estamos cagando a palos, pero igual está bien.
Muchísimas armas, todas distintas y mejorables.  
Alguna que otra decisión meh. Duración corta, y dificultad medianamente fácil, pero el juego te da los recursos para ir complicándotela a elección.

[b]¡Lo recomiendo![/b]

Full mosquete recortado.

[h1]8/10[/h1]

Now I do have 8 hours in this game because I finished this game twice. The first time was around 2-3 years ago and I thought I had a quick ending and missed a lot of content until the 'true' ending. After just finishing it for a second time, I now come to realize this wasn't the case and just got a different ending but that doesn't matter since it was a decent enough timekiller.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
A decent game if you get it on sale and even then don't expect too much with it since besides the art-style and maybe the soundtrack there's not much else to behold.

5,7/10

101927204.review:
"flavor" is a word that game designers sometimes use, i.e. "flavor text." I didn't understand the siginifcance of this design element until playing Bastion.

What makes this game unique is the narrator. He comments on almost everything you do, providing almost all of the story information, and delivers a lot of flavor text. The game would be just as enjoyable RPG without it, and the story could have been conveyed through dialogue boxes, but the choice to use narration does A LOT to help with the tone. The narrator speaks through bon mots, and has the voice of a grizzled frontiersman... the way he talks tells you so much about what the culture of Caelondia, the destroyed city you rebuild throughout the course of the game, once was like. It matches perfectly with the swampy-banjoed soundtrack.

Bastion is a hack n' slash, and the gameplay helps you achieve a deep understanding of the different weapons you can use. It has special "proving ground" challenges that ask you to play with your weapons more and more efficiently. In-game currency is scarce, forcing you to complete "vigils", special challenges like shooting 12 bullets in a row without missing, in order to get paid. Levelling is also slow: the game asks you to opt into added difficulty to get more XP and money.

I'm not a huge gamer, so maybe this mechanic isn't as revelatory to people who have played more RPGs than I have, but these are the design elements that make me enjoy Bastion.

100259415.review:
Third game from Supergiant that I've played (after Hades and Transistor in that order) and I'm not surprised to see where the quality of Hades came from. The thing is they've found a way to balance interesting mechanic with storytelling that even the most simplistic game is still a great experience. Bastion is the very start of it I'd say and is awesome. But before you buy it a few things to keep in mind:

General:
* Art is superb
* Storytelling is amazing
* Voice acting by Logan Cunningham is out of this world
* Everything else that I can't detail adds up
* But then the game is quite short. I did in 5ish hours, but I presume 3 hours should be more than enough for a first experience
*  Menu UI is weird or unconventional for games I'd say
* At least on my machine it stutters here and there. Nothing crazy, but since it can handle Monster Hunter World, Quantum Break and Control on ultra specs without even touching the fan this can be annoying

Mechanics
* Simple easy replayable rogue-lite-like
* Weapon loadout is really vast and you can do builds (but then the game doesn't seem to explore much of this aspect)
* Story mode poses no challenges, but the challenges are real challenges
* Part of the map allows you to fall and it doesn't quite follow visually. I've caught myself falling in places I though I'd stand while being able to fluctuate in other places where I should fall. So be careful with the edges
* Aiming doesn't seem to follow the cursor correctly. With the dart weapon (I forget the name) there is always a catch where to place your cursor. I always have to aim past the object and trust in the dart trajectory

99824152.review:
Bastion is one of the earliest games I was able to buy entirely by myself and while I did so originally via a Humble Bundle, also my first one, I wanted a bunch of the steam items, achievements, and the badge for it so I bought it again, 6 months later on steam. The sound-track kept me company for years travelling on public transport and will likely end up on every media playing device I own till the day I die.

I can absolutely recommend Bastion. It's one of my long-time, all-time, favourite games. I don't have a lot of hours in it, it doesn't have a ton of replay value unless you're playing a specific, score-based, mode which doesn't really interest me (Hades feels like a stronger contender for that sort of game play), but every now and again I get a hankering for the story and it's always been worth returning to.

For being over 10 years old now it's a beautifully realized game. The controls are tight, the combat is engaging, the weapons are diverse and each fun and effective in their own right. The price-tag is well worth it, I've paid it once and a half (Humble Bundle let me get it somewhat cheaper) and I'd pay it again if I ever lost access to my steam account.

The handful of times I've beaten it I've played little else between sessions and although it takes around 8 hours to beat all-up I reckon it would easily take me 10x that to complete based on some of the challenges and achievements available. Maybe one day I'll sit down and do the game the justice it deserves and 100% it.

Bastion taught to me give a chance to any and every Supergiant game that might come out, whether I think I'll like it or not. There isn't one yet I don't own and and not one I wouldn't recommend.

Bastion has wonderful artwork, captivating music, and engaging gameplay. it's one of the few games with fighting in its gameplay where i feel like it's hard to button spam and win, at least for the harder achievements. when playing casually, Bastion isn't a hard game, but you can adjust that difficulty level with game modes and idols. if you're going for the achievements, you do have to work a little harder, which is why i think it can appeal both to casual gamers and to those who want more of a challenge.

the main problem i have with this game is its lack of explanation for the storyline. there's little backstory for the world it's set in or for relations between the social groups in the game, as well as why the people in the game survived. the purpose of the Bastion is revealed only vaguely approaching the game's end and could have been alluded to better. i'm also not personally a fan of having a character explain the whole story, but i think Rucks had enough personality that it worked pretty well in this game. 

if story doesn't matter to you, Bastion is otherwise a great game.

99172624.review:
5/10

A quasi-platformer, action/adventure story with modest gear/level-up components and a focus on combat and simple "puzzle" tasks. I couldn't get into it myself, but that feels more like me not liking this type of game rather than a failure of the game to do its thing well.

Full disclosure, I did not finish the game as it was just too boring for me and I couldn't get into the story.

PROS:
-seems unique enough among games both in presentation style and in player experience. I've really not played anything quite like this before.
-combat is well balanced so that it is challenging without being unfair.
-visually it is a fun, half-cartoonish, colorful world.

CONS:
-I feel like this game can't quite decide what it wants to be. It has very limited aspects of lots of things: exploration, story-driven focus, loot, upgrades, combat, tasks/puzzles, platforming, etc. But no one thing really shines through. I got really tired of playing through levels that, though technically new, did not feel fresh or creative enough to keep my interest. It felt like I was going around the house putting a sock on different items. Sure it's novel and at times it can be challenging, but this isn't really fun at all and I am just wasting my time and wearing out my sock.
-I couldn't get into the story either. This one I am really not sure why, but this story is just boring to me. Maybe it was my mood during the period that I played or maybe I didn't play far enough into it (I got maybe halfway or more) or maybe the game really does just suck, story-wise. I simply couldn't care about the character, where he was going, or what was happening along the way and that is a big part of this game which is heavily plot-driven or, at least, the format of the game is plot-driven so the story is always in front of you to try and care about.

98598215.review:
As Supergiant's first game, Bastion is still a solid experience. The gameplay is open ended as it allows you to mix together the different weapons and skills you find along your journey. This is balanced by only allowing you to manage a few items in total. You can even add different difficulty conditions that give it more of a rouge-like feeling.

While exploring, the level's storytelling is intertwined with mostly narration. Character interactions aren't as common so if you're looking for an extremely detailed story this won't satisfy. Normally this approach can be boring or off putting but the writing is competent enough to still flesh out the world to a good degree. This is helped by most of the levels giving enough environmental detail to help you bridge the gap of how this world would feasibly operate outside of when the game takes place.

The overall run time for the game is on the shorter side with me finishing it in under 10 hours, however there is replay value for those interested in the gameplay loop. I believe the price is fair for what is given! If the time is a turn off Bastion is also hit pretty frequently when there are big site wide sales like the seasonal ones. If I had to give a score it would be a 7/10 :)

97854481.review:
[h1] 8.5/10 [/h1]

To some extent, Bastion definitely has a place in 2D Indie action games. The game, released in 2011, showed us the possibilities of 2D action games and not only was it well-received in the gaming world, but it was also ported to platforms such as XBOX 360 and IOS in the future, continuing to exude its luster even today.

The unique and interesting narrative narration adds a lot of interest to the plot, which is not very impressive in itself. With its unique worldview, melodious music, and relaxing atmosphere, I can understand why this game has gained so much popularity, and the freely selectable battle system provides players with a variety of strategic options.

Bastion, being an older game, will inevitably have drawbacks that cannot be avoided due to its age. The unique worldview in the game did not get a good play, and the playability and fun of the game with today's eyes to measure also inevitably slightly inferior. The overall length of the game is not long, and not a lot of playable modes is often difficult to make players produce more weekend play motivation.

Bastion as the production team to lay the foundation of the production style of the game has been quite good. But it is after all a game released in 2011, and although it has not faded, players may need to consider whether they can accept its shortcomings. Personally, I think the group's Hades can almost be called a sequel to this game, in terms of gameplay, and core mechanics are more or less inherited and improved. If you like the gameplay and worry about the age of the problem, try Hades is also a good choice.

97689683.review:
Play this game if you
- Enjoy a strong and somewhat engrossing story
- Like flashy and punchy combat
- Appreciate well-made visuals and a captivating setting

Don't play this game if you
- Expect a really tight and perfect combat system
- Dislike story being near-forced onto you


Bastion is very quaint. It mixes together fairly unorthodox styles and ideas in storytelling, visuals and gameplay to an odd effect, but in such a way that you'll want to see where it goes and how it pans out. The protagonist is "The Kid", a silent and blank, but necessary and relevant individual who is abruptly spurned into action by the calamity, a disaster that has destroyed most of the known world. He's led by the double time character and narrator Locke to the eponymous Bastion, a special structure that may be some sort of a solution to the currently ailing world. From there, the kid is tasked with finding energy-rich shards to restore the Bastion.

It's a slightly rushed premise that's perhaps a little too eager, but it's well-realized enough to give a background of sense to the journey and all of the unusual and slightly wacky places visited. These places are wonderfully unique in person: old, classical architecture full of civil-war era stylings, strange toxic swamps and barren, dilapidated factories that all centre around a western theme and imbue the game with a desolate, out-on-the-frontier feeling.

Although Bastion has an impressively dense and well-crafted atmosphere, it would be lacking without the exciting action of the combat. It's not finely-tuned and perfectly smooth, with timing and telegraphing being off and controls having a rough feel to them. However, it's flashy, reactive and there's enough variety in enemies and weapons to keep gameplay interesting and eventful.

If the aspects listed so far captured your attention, then the plot will hold your interest. It's dark and largely mysterious, and involves heavy subject matter. It's not that the existence of these themes and plot points is special, but the overall boldness of the game in this area makes for a tense and immersive experience.

Perhaps the greatest thing about Bastion to me is that it feels like newly-explored territory in gaming, even today. There's no question that nothing specific about it really stands, and some parts are even quite cliche and mainstream, but sum total it's a memorable and original experience. As one of the early indie darlings, it no doubt exemplified the different and zany ideas characteristic of many to come.

8/10

Bastion is the first game Supergiant Games ever released, and from here they went on to make (as of writing) Pyre, Transistor, and Hades. All of Supergiant's games are critically acclaimed, and Bastion is certainly no exception.

If you have played any of Supergiant's other games, and have not yet played Bastion, I highly recommend you do so. 
If you have *not* played any of Supergiant's other games, I still highly recommend you play Bastion.
It has an interesting story with memorable characters, a fantastic combat system with many, many different weapons and abilities to choose from and unlock, intricate level design where no level feels the same as the last, a gorgeous art style viewed from an isometric viewpoint, fantastic voice work, and a fantastic soundtrack.

Bastion was the first game Supergiant would release, and it was certainly not the last, due in no small part to the success it brought them, and it did so only because it is such a great game. I highly recommend it to anyone interested.

97289014.review:
Bastion is a lite ARPG, in which you play "the Kid" (the only name you are ever given) as he makes his way through a post-apocalyptic world to restore order. Featuring beautiful, hand-painted floating worlds, a sweeping soundtrack and quite possible the greatest narrator ever, Bastion is a gem of a game and deserves to be experienced.

You begin your quest to rebuild the world, going through various environments and trying to piece things back together. As you progress, you unlock new weapons and special abilities (which in some cases are tied to a particular weapon) - these are tied to world and story progression, with some abilities being linked directly or indirectly towards challenges and are presented as rewards. The other elements which lend a "lite" RPG tinge are the potions (which are unlocked by character level and provide various boosts and sometimes drawbacks as well), and the idol system which can be toggled. Some idols speed up the enemies, make them hit harder, enable them to dodge, remove health potion drops, etc. which effectively gives the game a customisable difficulty.

The most notable part though is the Narrator. Your story is told to you from waking, through the levels and right up to the end, relayed by the Narrator. The mechanic in itself is perhaps nothing remarkable, but the voice acting for this particular role is superb and really gives the game its character - the fact that some of the Narrator's statements are contextual (i.e. one section has the Narrator commenting on how many times you fall, if at all) just heightens the immersion. The constant voice is the most crucial aspect of this game and something it does astonishingly well. The soundtrack (which is also superb!) is the other part of the audio masterpiece that is Bastion, and is worth mention in its own right.

There is not much replayability here (story wise at least, challenge wise you can vary it almost to your heart's content) - but if this is a genre you enjoy, you should play Bastion at least once. Highly recommended.

Played on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any issues.

97241100.review:
[b]Last played on: August 2021.[/b]
[i]My verdict is at the bottom.[/i]
[url=https://raggartsreviews.com/reviews/bastion/]Read the full review, with pictures[/url]
[h2]A Sleeper Gem[/h2]
Before Bastion I liked playing video games. Thanks to this game, I can now say I LOVE playing video games. I can’t put my finger on what it is exactly that I like so much about it. Maybe it was simply the game I needed at that point in my life? It felt just like you find a book, movie or music album that just resonates.

The music is perfect, the narration adds a lot to the immersion, the gameplay is sharp and the story is captivating. All of these put together make for one of my favourite games of all time.
[h2]A Calamity for the ages[/h2]
Bastion is an isometric action platformer where you play the part of the Kid waking up after the Calamity. Wandering around and exploring parts of his beautiful post-apocalyptic world, the Kid seeks survivors as well as answers. What caused everyone to turn to stone? What lies beyond the Wall? Venture forth while slaying all manner of beasts to find out.

I found the story, about hope, the future and how to (re)build it, quite appealing. The world’s lore and history are revealed little by little, with every level and stage, through the narrator’s gritty voice. There’s also “dream-like” levels (called “Who Knows Where”) where the personal story of each of the characters is revealed in greater details - if you can beat enough stages.

The story is well defined enough that even the various weapons, mementos and spirits have a unique story or description. It has been a while since I played the game for the first time but I remember I was really gripped by the story and wanted to finish the game as quickly as possible to finally have all the answers. Fortunately, every level, every step forward, reveals more of Bastion so you can enjoy the game and learn the story and lore at the same time.
[h2]A story told[/h2]
The music, sound and especially the narration, play a big role in this game. I felt a bit let down by the Kid’s voice and found the sound effects ordinary. They hit all the right notes but don’t pop out any more than that. The narration, though, helps with immersion and reveals the story while never breaking the flow of play. It also helps cement the emotional investment.

An added benefit of the narration is that there is no need to scroll through walls of text or press buttons to engage in lengthy conversations. The flow of the game and the pace of the story is mostly seamless.
[h2]An inspiration for many years[/h2]
Bastion came out in 2011, more than 10 years ago! It’s a testament to the quality of game-making skills of the original seven members of Supergiant Games that the game is still so good after all this time.

If you play Bastion now and you have played other games in the same genre before, you will not find much that is new. At the time though, it contained a lot of novelty. The narration as story development, in particular, was unheard of. The devs really hit the nail on the head with this one.

Today it’s still a fun game with a lot of production value, including a New Game + mode - allowing you to replay the game with all the upgrades you had unlocked in the previous playthrough - if you feel so inclined.
[h2]Verdict[/h2]
As you can probably guess by all the praise written so far, I give the game a glowing recommendation. However it’s not for everybody. You have to enjoy isometric games, you have to like action-RPGs and I think you should play it with a controller. If you like games where music is important, you should also like Bastion.
[h3]What I liked most about the game[/h3]
The narrator! Also, the way every weapon and combination of spirits and weapon revealed its true potential after playing with them for a while.
[h3]What I liked the least about the game[/h3]
How the end felt less fully developed than the start. At the start, the narrator will say random interesting things depending on how you play (“The Kid just rages for a while”). Towards the end everything is much more streamlined and I missed that special flavour.

Also, sometimes it’s hard to tell how to move through some of the sprites so you might get stuck during combat.
[h3]Should I buy this game?[/h3]
If you like this type of game, absolutely. Maybe watch a video or two before buying but for $15 I think you get more than your money’s worth. Also, it’s frequently on sale so you might get it for cheaper if you wait a bit.

96412082.review:
[h1] Bastion - 9.2/10 [/h1]

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b] 9.5/10, 10/10
[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b] 10/10
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] 7.0/10
[b] Graphics: [/b] 5.0/10
[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b] 9.0/10, 7.0/10

[b] Plot and Dialogue: [/b]
The plot of Bastion is presented in a unique manner, with a narrator commenting on your actions in real time, instead of having your character talking in the moment. It's the only game that I've played that has done it in this manner, and it does it extremely well. The dialogue is top notch, without any corny or cringey lines. Each line and word contributes to the greater story at hand. The plot itself seems simple at the beginning, until you start to dive into the environment and the world you are playing in. The ending is especially strong, one of the strongest I've seen. 

[b] Setting and Art Design: [/b]
The setting and art design is phenomenal in this game, with each level feeling extremely distinct and memorable. Each character also has a great design to them, even though they have the same base model. The various structures, colors, and environments that are all used mesh very well to immerse you in this great world. 

[b] Soundtrack: [/b]
The soundtrack enhances the scene you are in, with there being some pretty good ones. A majority of the tracks though were mostly forgettable. The ones that were memorable are, In Case of Trouble, A Proper Story, Build That Wall (Zia's Theme), Mother I'm Here (Zulf's Theme), and Setting Sail, Coming Home (End Theme). Each of these tracks are done very well, bringing up the emotions that are needed to convey for each character. 

[b] Graphics: [/b]
The graphics are not great, but that does not really matter. The game looks good and so I don't really dock the game for anything, graphics wise.

[b] Gameplay and Sound Design: [/b]
The gameplay is extremely varied, allowing the player to fine tune the weaponry selection, their tonics, and spells to suit each play style. The level design is linear, but it is still fun and offers some paths that are not on the straight line for the player to explore. The enemy design is also very well done, as each enemy is distinct. The game also introduces different enemies at the end of the game, to keep the player on their toes. That was done well. There are also additional side content that you can do to better master your weapons, but are not mandatory. The sound design has some nice sounds to it as well, each your weapons sounding very distinct. Good on that. 

[b] Final Notes: [/b]
This game, even though it is about 10 years old now, is still an extremely good game that everyone should play. It isn't long, but offers plenty of replayaability for those that enjoy replayability.

96128895.review:
Juego indie al que le falta pulido.

Concretamente la dificultad de algunos enemigos es fruto de un mal diseño. Las plantas de cactus que disparan espinas son tediosas de matar al principio. El triceratops saltarín no tiene una distancia de salto fijo y no puede ser atacado por delante, resultando muy difícil colocarse detrás de él: si estás lejos no puedes atacar, si estás cerca, salta un centímetro y te pisa.

¿Por qué te dan dinero por romper una barandilla?

La reconstrucción del mundo según se avanza es un efecto visual que no comprendo. ¿Por qué sucede? Pretende ser bonito pero es recargado y distrae.

La voz del narrador es un error. LO CUENTA TODO. ¿Te queda una poción? Lo cuenta. ¿Matas un enemigo? Lo cuenta. Un narrador es otra cosa, alguien que cuenta lo necesario, no alguien que dice "se rascó el culo" cuando te lo rascas. Cuéntame la historia, no los movimientos de mi cuerpo.

Otro detalle es que el narrador le resta protagonismo y personalidad a los demás personajes: el chico no tiene voz ¡ni siquiera cuando ataca o lo hieren!, los demás secundarios tampoco. Así que no pueden mostrar enfado ni alegría.

Increíble que, con un 97% de recomendaciones, [b]sólo un 15% haya terminado el juego[/b] (ver logros mundiales).

95294229.review:
Well after its initial release, this game is still holding up as a short-but-sweet experience. The gameplay itself is simple but relatively varied with mechanics that allow the player to tailor the difficulty to their taste. My only critique here is that though there are many weapon choices, I found myself gravitating only to a couple of the options and sticking with that even after rolling over to NG+. I'm not sure if there's an "optimal" setup, but I suspect there are some weapons that are just objectively better than others, and this may bother some players looking for a lot of depth. 

The level progression is quite smooth with minimal time spent on exposition at the expense of gameplay. As I understand, this was a conscious decision made by the dev, and one that I believe was well-executed. The ubiquitous narration carries the player through and tells the story in impressionistic strokes as the game progresses.

The art style is colorful and appealing, which combines with an interesting and beautiful musical score to make a very polished presentation. For those looking for a short, fun action game with a simple but enjoyable narrative experience, I'd fully recommend giving this a try if you hadn't already.

94655041.review:
[h1] Supergiant comes out swinging [/h1] 

Bastion was a title I looked at when it came out, knowing I had to check it out, but it took me many years to eventually get to it. Since then it grew into a bit of a phenomenon, so did it live up to the huge expectations?

Simply put, yes it did. In more words, I can see why the game became the hit that placed Supergiant Games on the map, even so there's a tiny "yes, but" to this, even if it's more of a nitpick. I felt by the end that the skill system could've used a bit more customisation to play around with. When I played Transistor directly after this one, with it's mix and match skill system, I knew it was exactly something of the sort I'd have loved to have seen in Bastion.

That tiny nitpick aside, Bastion is a must play and a big thumbs up!

[b] Pros [/b] 
[list]
    [*]Beautiful art style and a soundtrack that will stay with you long after the game has ended
    [*]Fun and responsive gameplay with a variety of enemies to take on
    [*]An interesting form of level design with a patch work world that's being laid out at your feet as you play
[/list] 

[b] Cons[/b] 
[list]
    [*]The game feels a tad on the short side, but that's partly due to...
    [*]Skills and abilities not as fleshed out, I'd have loved something like Transistor's mixing up skill system being implemented into the world of Bastion
[/list]

93783273.review:
A fun hack&slash action game taken place in a slightly unusual visual setting.

I enjoyed my time with this one. Relatively easy to get into with a good mix of mechanics and weapons to make it difficult to master. There's an unlockable game-mechanic where you can increase the difficulty in specific ways but in return gain more progression for the various upgrades in the game. This allows for a more fine-tuned experience than the usual approach of preset difficulty options.

The art-style is really fantastic and stylized in a way that ages very well. 

Sound design is good, the various sounds of projectiles and weapon attacks etc does the job. The narrator will narrate (what a surprise) what is happening on screen in addition to the story-line beats. I find the narrator helps set the tone of the world and does a good job of it.

I felt like the game length for each play-through is at the right spot for the amount of content the game offers, although when going for 100% achievements it may feel like it drags to some extent, depending on skill level. It can be quite brutal at maximum difficulty going for some of the combat arenas and even doing the standard game.

Definitely worth a pickup on a sale for fans of the genre.

93541164.review:
I played this game back on the Xbox 360 when it first came out. I was looking through and thought I'd jump into it on the PC... FIVE hours later(!) haha

It still holds up so well; I'm playing with a controller and, in all honesty, its the type of game that plays much better on a controller in my view.

They have a great concept of raising the difficulty with a risk/reward system by way of activating idols that can be collected- akin to the skulls in Halo as modifiers. It works well as, whilst they aren't necessary, they help to ramp up the difficulty as your skills and upgrades progress.

The art direction lends itself to not look dated at all.. And the music, if you haven't already heard of it, is a treat. It will remain with you for a while after you've closed it. The sound design is well thought out; especially with the narration.

If you've not yet played it then I wholeheartedly recommend this. Classic.

93497584.review:
For the weapon challenges you'll most likely need to wait until you have the upgrades for most of them so if you can't finish them all first time come back later.

For the Machete Challenge stand in the middle of the arena where all the squirks spawn at the beginning and kill these before moving around the map to finish the others off.

For the shield challenge use the upgrades which makes you deal more damage when you counter, this'll help immensely along with the ability to move quicker while defending. If there's any enemies you struggle on countering you can always roll into them to damage them instead of countering, takes a while but is an easy way to get some the trickier counters.

All items you miss in game are available to buy in the Lost & Found, so don't worry too much if you've missed something.

93436871.review:
There are some games that play at the edges of your memories years after you have played them.  Games that, even when you may run across levels that feel excessively difficult, you want nothing more than to complete it and allow the melancholy-filled satisfaction to flow.  Bastion is a pleasing game visually, audibly, and story-wise, with game mechanics that are both challenging and easy to utilize.  There are some bumpy rides throughout but nothing that cannot be overcome with some time and focus.  There is a smoothness to the pacing that feels right—you go from fast action to a, well, bastion of peace where you recover and steady yourself for the next fight, uncovering and building up an existence for you and…others.  The story that unweaves is incredible, with voice talent so compelling that you can’t get the narrator’s voice out of your head.  And you won’t want to.

If you are not used to this kind of gameplay but are willing to try it, Bastion is a great introduction.  Pick up the soundtrack while you are at it—it is unique.

92712532.review:
At this point Hades is getting all the attention, but Supergiant has yet to make....even a meh game. Of the three games before Hades, Bastion is unquestionably the best in terms of gameplay.

In a nutshell, Bastion excels because it presents enemies that do exactly one thing that needs exactly one thing to counter it, then throws you an assortment of weapons that don't work well against ALL of them. Yeah, it pioneered the Supergiant Narrative Experience TM, and it's truly reliably pretty for both the eyes and ears, but the game is nothing without its concise, direct, responsive gameplay.

Don't skip this one. It truly is rewarding.

this game is what you would call a basic b!tch

do yourself a favor and do not even bother. i can assure you even if you give the game a chance you will play it for 30 minutes and never touch it again, and it will rot in your steam library.

[*]the polish is there, let's not kid ourselves. after all this is one of the predecessors of HADES
[*]the music, narration and visual style are amazing. the character model is garbage tho. it is the only thing in the game that is a 3d model when everything is painted sprites.
[*]gameplay feels good but it is just boring.
[*]steam lists "RPG" as a genre-tag, the game has no rpg elements tho. the only thing you could call progression in this game is leveling up to level 10. each level up lets you equip 1 potion that gives some kind of bonus and 2 more hitpoints. after that xp does nothing.
[*]you collect fragments as a currency which you can use to buy upgrade-items, new special abilities, potions or upgrade every weapon up to 5 times. after that currency is useless and can not be spent.
[*]the games achievements suck ass and are not fun to do or way too hard.
[*]if you straight up just finish the storyline and play through the levels without exploring much the game is only about 3 hours long
[*]you do not get to wear any kind of equipment or armor. your characters visual appearance never changes.
[*]you get to equip 2 weapons out of 12 and one special ability. most of them suck or feel bad to use.
[*]there are no boss fights except a couple of larger enemies that take 3-4 hits instead of 1 or 2.
[*]the game never grips you, just ride along listening to the narrator that is interesting for about 30 minutes and gets annoying after that. the game does not really have a story or character development.

A hyper charming game that was ahead of it's time, the core gameplay is fun, and the weapons are varied enough to make you want to shift between the different weapons. You also get them at a pretty consistent rate over a relatively short game that doesn't drag too badly, albeit it feels meh to have a large number of samey things you need to collect for some random future goal (very ps3/xbox 360 game development). Luckily the game is just enjoyable to play, though there is a pretty cool world.

Worth getting on sale, worth playing through, I might not play it again, and if I do, it'll be years from now when I've ripped apart my backlog, but it was a memorable and charming game that I'm glad I played.

91374807.review:
As fresh as it was ten years ago on release, Jen Zee's art is timeless and Logan Cunningham's narration steers you along with a nicely dry humour while Darren Korb's soundtrack ties the whole game together.

It's a beautiful and touching ARPG as you steer the Kid into piecing together the remaining pieces of a destroyed world. 

It's regularly on sale or bundled with other Supergiant Games and I'd definitely recommend picking it up in either of those two ways. It's a game to be experienced.
